zLhMtsyOmqlNXvxt8NCm1Q.text: Let's keep this review simple:Incredibly annoying place with ridiculously overpriced food that looks good under the fancy lights but tastes no better than any authentic bakery round the corner. You can buy a loaf of bread here for 7 POUNDS. For 1 loaf. I kid you not Mr Moneybags!Princi simply seems to be about looking good and being expensive. It's the food equivalent to the make-up and perfume stands that clutter the entrance to every department store.

yb_nSb09Bc1Rnl0cd-1GJw.text: This is taking the phrase, "you eat with your eyes" to a whole new level. Displays of desserts, pizzas, flatbreads (I guess that's what you call it), paninis, pastas, hot entrees, salads, and more! Like a kid in a candy shop. On the other side of the restaurant, there's a sit-down area for customized pizzas. Dangerous to go hungry as you might just want everything. So many choices, not enough room to eat it all!

2IXSx83QVHkG3rlHangdFA.text: Great for breakfast, great for lunch, great for dinner, great for tea, great for coffee. My all time fav pizzeria.

fv7Woc6tEtcrKw2Rtw5y9Q.text: Quite posh, but a nice place to get a coffee and catch-up with friends

swKlSxnxiTeqdovHNiGPBQ.text: My friends and I were roaming the streets of London and happened to look into the window of Princi around dinner time.  I saw a man inside who looked to be enjoying a beautiful pizza.  As we made eye contact, he took a big bite of his pizza and then give us a very enthusiastic thumbs up!We were on our way to Jamie Oliver's Italian joint when this happened, and after going by and being told that the wait would be over an hour, we found our way back over to Princi.  We ended up waiting for about 35 minutes here, but keep in mind that it was around 8:30 on a Friday, so it was to be expected that we would have to wait a bit.But let me tell you, the wait was WORTH IT!  There was three of us and we ordered two starter salads and three pizzas and were very satisfied by the end.  I ordered one of the simpler pizzas towards the top of the menu with buffala mozzarella and it was unreal how delicious it was!  Service was pretty good too and were it not for the fact that we were completely stuffed after the pizzas, I would have totally ordered dessert b/c all of their million options looked absolutely scrumptious!  I don't live in London, but my friends who were with me do, and I have insisted that they need to go back and confirm the deliciousness of the pastries here!

qNPPmnPleQp6ME8B8-S0zg.text: GREAT pastries.  Good sandwiches - though the ciabatta was a bit limp (and who wants a limp ciabatta ;-)?!).Decent cappuccino.Crap service.  They don't have the concept of a queue, and the staff glides in front of the patrons with nary a look. I have zero problem with being a tad aggressive in flagging them down, but would rather save myself the aggravation, and since I like Paul's just as well, it's Princi 0, Paul's 1.

JTdP8HoKkzNnyxZY-ryfgg.text: Terrible.  Overpriced, pretentious and awful service.  Waited nearly 30 minutes and my poached eggs never came.  Americano obviously had dead shots.  Couldn't flag a waiter.  Finally got a refund and left.  Surprised this place has made it on Wardour Street with all the great options available just feet away.

wVC1yAWC_IqowTyFOaZ1Hg.text: Not quite top rated on Italians' websites. But it succeed in Soho. Tried twice, cake, salad, breads.   Tiramisu was great.  Turkey salad and chilli garlic broccoli salad was sooo good.  Focaccia slices were really depends on your luck. First time there, I found my focaccia was too greasy and taste wired. But the last, my tomato focaccia and the olive one, both taste like heaven. Even I left them overnight. Without oven reheat, still taste wonderful.  Highly recommend their Turkey lentils salad,and broccoli. Super healthy and full of flavour:) never feel enough

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

3rqp7lLkLnA7TbEoqEIFfQ.text: I used to always come to Princi for a quick lunch - the over-baked pizzas with proscuitto and melted cheese are just so good! But inevitably the prices have increased and service has gotten surly. It's quite hard to get a table, and once you're done eating, the staff are quick to usher you out the door. The salads aren't the best and the options are rather limited for the price. 7-8 pounds for a "big plate" which barely fits 3 selections! The cakes now are about £4.5 a slice which in my opinion is too steep although the passionfruit cheesecake is still to die for. They stopped making the chocolate eclairs which were my favourite dessert overall which is another thing that I wish they didn't change! All in all, used to be one of my favourite Soho hangouts that got ruined by the surly service, ridiculous price increases, and difficulty in getting a table.

EqSxI5YOO7UiqzBKMf4EMw.text: The place could be nice, food is good but expensive for what it is, quite pretentious which makes the experience of a "posh cafeteria" less enjoyable. Staff at the take away section and cashier guys are oh so rude. I'll give it a miss next time!

wxLxp9OUCpCO6IaVgccVoA.text: This place...what a place. Casual, easy, not fussy at all...but they sure do take their food seriously. Love their olive bread, their authentically Italian flavours, the sheer visual delight of an array of savoury and sweet offerings. There aren't a lot of places in London or elsewhere which can offer what Princi does - a reasonably priced, centrally located, well-designed gastronomic experience which can be accessed easily, without bookings, without crazy queuing (at least on weekends when I am there), without pompousness... may there be more Princi's in this world, prays this food-lover!

vE6xTmNIgpPKvojHbSR5ow.text: After a long day at work capped by an average dinner, and suffering a bit from jet lag, I set out in search of an establishment that met a few important criteria:1 - that it be open late2 - that it be located within reasonable walking distance3 - that it provide top notch pastries that would be worth eating at midnightPrinci fit the bill. I was surprised to see people waiting behind the velvet rope despite the late hour. Fortunately, given that I was not looking for a table, I was able to get right inside. The place is beautiful, and the pastries and bakery items are nicely arranged, making it somewhat more difficult to make a decision. The question remained: would everything taste as good as it looked?Almost everything rated highly.They were out of one of the items I was looking for. Neither of the two versions of their Mille Foglie listed on the menu was available. Too bad. I'm always on the lookout for  good interpretation of the classic mille feuilles, whatever language it's said it.Instead, I went for the Selva Nera (black forest). It was near perfect. Perfectly balanced, creamy, not overly sweet, and with just a hint of cherries. I could have eaten a half-dozen without missing a beat.I also got the amaretto and chocolate trancia, which provided quite a contrast to the Selva Nera. Dense, heavy, rich, yet delectable. You'll either need to share it with someone or make it your entire meal.As a big fan of pistachio in general, I couldn't help but also get a slice of the peach and pistachio cake. Nicely flavored, dense, but a bit dry, it was a bit of a let-down after the other two. Maybe it was because of the late hour, or maybe it was because I was on my third cake. I'd like to give it another try, just to make sure.I'll be returning to Princi again and again. Style and substance, all day and evening long.

pzpLg2XHc_dRTREuQtz5UA.text: I think this is probably the best pizza joint in London. The toppings are such good quality produce and the base is the perfect consistency. Very hard to get a table.

vNahNdbRNWNJwEE2gxHtwA.text: I wish there was a 2.5 option. This place is ok. Not great but certainly not bad either. It's an updated business model of the traditional Panetteria/focacceria. Unfortunately it's also a paragon of style over substance, which is quite fitting for a chain originating from Milan. I totally agree with the "eat with your eyes" comment on one of the reviews - the vast selection from pastries and pizzette to sfogliatell' and cannoli. Almost all the food behind the counter looks awesome, resulting in an overwhelming desire to order one of everything. Taste-wise however, speaking as an italian, it's not all that. particularly re the pizze - there are several genuinely authentic Neapolitan or even Roman pizzerie in London (Donna Margherita; Sartori/Santorè, Finos to name but a few). Their cannoli are not appreciably better than those you can buy over the counter at bar Italia or Lina's Deli, the price however is appreciably higher. Oh, and the coffee ain't great.That said, it does have a great selection of both savory and sweet food, it's in a great location, and if you can tolerate the bedlam surrounding the seating hunt, then it's a good place to pop into for a quick bite.

HK9Zl9_gYyvdvcCF3ZlAwQ.text: The tables are set humblyback from the busyness round the counters and up beside the wall on the farside there are little cascades and a bit of a marble look going on.

k74gcTnALyTRo3vLZVvd3g.text: Went out of my way to give this place a try. I went around 3pm today (friday) hoping there wouldn't be a crowd, however i was very wrong. I can see what everyone means about trying to get a seat! It's quite hard. I walked in, and took a look at everything they offered, and you definitely have to just grab a server's attention cause i stood there for ages trying to decide what i wanted and then to actually order it.... There was a whole section of sweets, then pizza, then bread/stuff then some pasta-ish dishes which really probably wasn't pasta but i can't seem to remember what they were...and at the end are the drinks. I ordered a pepperoni pizza, a slice of it for 4.30 pounds which was quite pricy so i picked the biggest piece and pointed it out to him when i finally got his attention. Then i also ordered a small cappuccino for 2.30 pounds. I grabbed a seat at table with these random people and was just listening to what they were talking about, tv shows and how if they were american or british and if they liked it or not. haha, quite amusing while i ate. I guess they are suppose to take your tray away after you get to your table. That's cool. I wouldn't know what to do with it either. And they clean up after you leave. There's only a bathroom for each gender and a disabled you can use as well. The pizza was okay, it wasn't anything extra special, but since it was just outta the oven it was quite hot and yummy, it was very thick which i loveee and i was going to choose another pizza but this was new...and looked mighty appetizing. The cappuccino was okay, nothing special about that either.. It's a bit high of a price for average food, but service was nice and i did sample practically everything while i waited...moving down each counter..lol and the person who made my cappuccino probably noticed i was american and i had only said "cappuccino" to him...so he was telling me to try this sample that was offered in italy or something during christmas, and it was good, though i already had a piece when i came in :P I probably would only come back to try the dessert next time, but they are over 3 pound at least... so have to think about that!

CQahMaRNf3BpzytoYeFy3Q.text: I stumbled in here after having a few drinks around Soho.  It's open late and the pizza was freshly pipin' hot.  For the typical drunkard like me on a Saturday night, I was grateful not having to resort to Mickey D's or the typical kebab.  Yes, it is a little expensive but it's so nice and shiny!  (I suppose I wouldn't expect any less in Soho!)  Second time here I stopped by in the afternoon for coffee and cakes.  It was delightful but it is busy.  Get ready to use those elbows!  I'll definitely be back for more.

rt-EEI1LAJARqGHR6pZJJA.text: I've been known to traverse the city in hopes of finding the perfect pizza. Some have come close, others not so much. However, It is safe to say my pizza hunting adventures are over now that I have made it to Princi. Having convinced a friend that Princi was a Pizza place, and therefore Italian and probably did risotto (which is what she wanted), off we went to Princi. For the record, the pizzeria is just Pizza (with 2 pasta options).Nonetheless, we got seated rather quickly and were greeted by out waiter with a very Italian "Yes?". That must be Italian for may I help you... I ordered the Veriso and a friend the Margarita with various other toppings (they kindly let her pick and choose her selection of toppings as she didn't quite fancy any of the predetermined ones - very accommodating). The food came quickly and we swiftly started our delicious pizzas. The dough was a little more thick than a normal Italian pizza, but absolutely amazing. The toppings were fresh and crust perfectly golden. Verdict? Great location, decent prices, and good service. I will definitely be back!

RaAeK81qhyy4Jdb-dRnrFQ.text: This is a combination of a Subway, a fine italian deli, and a buffet on steroids. It's kind of fantastic.You walk in, sort of have to fight for someone to help you because there's always a queue of a few people for the different subcategories of pizza, pasta, and salads - but once you do, you pay for your lovely authentic delicacies, and devour reaping a sort of tuscan orgasm in your mouth.It's not the cheapest option around for a hearty meal, but I gladly pay for variety, quality, and nutritious yumminess.

1voGEQTpFyf1VIVgPDut0Q.text: Princi is a fun place to go for lunch with a group. It gets quite hectic inside during lunch hours, but it's definitely worth it. Lots of options, and great variety to choose from so everyone in the group will be happy. Noise level was a little high but the food makes up for it. Large window facing the street which makes people watching fun. In the heart of Soho, fun location.

I2JGD7xtPOp0d-oE8R60dA.text: Big Ben.  Buckingham Palace.  The London Eye.  Princi.  Yes, Princi.  It needs to be on your list of must-sees when in London.  Ham sandwiches on a croissant.  Prosciutto on little "cigars" of olive bread.  Cheese on raisin bread.  All kinds of focacia.  And the desserts.  God, the desserts.  Looking back at my credit card bills, it was a rare day that didn't involve two trips to Princi,  Is it organized?  Nope.  Is the service friendly and welcoming?  Usually not.  Will you care?  Not a chance!

0idJB2jZqdnMUcwR4Nwn3w.text: BEWARE: PICKPOCKETS OPERATE AT THIS ESTABLISHMENT. A slice of pizza could cost you a small fortune. Consider going elsewhere. I am Italian and I make a point to visit Princi multiple times every time I travel to London (which is at least 3-4 times a year). The food is quite authentic and the presentation is nice, prices are pretty high, but worth it for us, since it is difficult to find good Italian food where we live, unfortunately though the place is always very busy and pickpockets have found their way in this establishment which has ruined the experience entirely for us. I don't think I will ever go back. In our last trip to London we arrived to London late morning, checked into our hotel nearby and walked to Princi for lunch. The food is ordered at a long counter with cashier point at the end of it, drinks are paid for at the same location, however they are collected at a separate bar counter.It was a Saturday at around 2pm, my husband paid for food and drinks while I looked for seating and then he moved towards the bar counter. The thieves must have spotted him putting his wallet away before heading to the other counter and his credit cards where stolen while he was waiting for the beverages. While we were eating the thieves went on a £5,000.00 (five thousand pounds) shopping spree in nearby establishments.How do I know it happened at Princi? Because we did not stop anywhere else. We went straight from the hotel to Princi. My husband's cards were all in his wallet when he paid for food and right after lunch we walked straight back to the hotel which is literally 3 minutes away. It could have not happened anywhere else. I am pretty sure this has happened before and I wonder if management has done anything to prevent it. Shame on them!

1iBd5yz5sio4J3DS0mspig.text: My go to spot for mornings and late nights. Food: 4.5, Atmosphere: 4, Service: 4Cost to worth it rating: 3Eve award: their chocolate croissants are out of this worldReturn worthiness: yes!Highlights:- Chocolate croissant: crispy and flaky with just enough chocolate inside- Mini croissants: better for the waistline - Breakfast sandwiches: had one with egg and meat and enjoyed it- Pizza: outstanding Italian style. Had the margarita and was delish- Easy: order at counter- Atmosphere: open, bright, lively - Wine: nice to have even with a casual mealLowlights:- Dangerous if I'm staying somewhere where it's on my path to work in the morning as its near impossible not to stop Love this place and I'm a regular when I'm in town.

P6lkbhzDfwXpFBI27zfZTA.text: wow. I'm not sure I've had a better dessert in all of London.I know I was only in London for a couple weeks- but ALL of my meals consisted of a dessert.  So after ... a couple...dozen..that I tried back to back- I absolutely adore this place as a nice place to stop by with a group and grab a chocolate-lemon-I-don't-know-what-it-is-called-but-it-was-delicious.Yes.

bIIloUNirO9q91S3LW-HXQ.text: Pasta porzioni piccolissime - Pasta portions extra extra smallThe linguine alle vongole very extra extra small and when I asked whether they were as a main, I was told that 90 grams of pasta is the rule for a main, although the waitress agreed that it is far too small. Such a portion for 10.50 GBP is ridiculous.The pizza is Okish, not amazing at all.Una porzione di pasta da 90gr sono 10.50 GBP, quasi 15 euro. Sono ancora di stucco e anche se la cameriera ci ha dato ragione non e' che serva a molto. Abbiamo dovuto fare un secondo pranzo altrove. La pizza va abbastanza bene ma non eccezzionale.

5nfMFS7PdPIjEbqwhEMdPA.text: My first morning in London, found me a bit jet lagged and surprisingly hungry. I noticed next to my little doggy bed a breakfast menu for the hotel, which stated that their breakfast came from Princi Bakery in Soho. Instead of having breakfast in bed, I decided to get myself cleaned up and go to their restaurant. And here is where the review gets tricky.The restaurant is beautifully designed open and inviting. The center of the room holds the wood-fire grill for what is supposed to be their famous pizza's from Milan. Yes, this is a Milanese restaurant. A not so friendly waiter who seemed to be having a bad morning greeted us. After dropping off the menu, he quickly left. We waited, and waited a bit more before he returned to take our order. Once again we waited, and waited, and waited some more. The waiter had simply vanished he was nowhere to be seen. Finally a woman came to our table (after a good 20 minutes) to ask if we were okay, we explained what had happened, she apologized and immediately corrected the situation. Our juice, cappuccinos, and pastries were brought to our table.The pastries were out of the world. Coming from the United States where you're never sure what you'll get when a croissant is ordered, this was truly amazing. Now I know what true French pastries are like. During our meal, we had three other employees of the restaurant checking in with us, including the manager (I believe) and it wasn't until the plates were cleared that our mysterious waiter with the attitude showed up. And once again after passing by our table a half-dozen times I literally had to stop him and ask for our bill.After talking to friends about this experience, I'm told that it's not uncommon to have such dramas unfold at some of the finest Milan restaurants, so if this is true than this place is spot on for bringing the essence of Milan to Soho.If you don't mind a bit of drama and emotional meltdown from your wait staff, then this place is worth the trip.Shatasdogbowl

CTe_4kDq2td94BPbhq8CpA.text: Love the concept and the location.  Perfect for a quick lunch.  However, it is so chaotic in there!  It is very confusing as to how to order, what to order, where to order, etc...and the workers expect you to know, and were not very happy that I didn't know.  After hopping from station to station, I decided on a slice of pizza and a caprese salad.  The pizza wasn't very good - I'm sure it would have been lovely if it was fresh and warm.  But I could tell it had been sitting there for quite some time as the cheese started to harden on top and the crust was soggy.  The salad was great - but it's not hard to do a mozzarella, tomato and basil salad wrong.  The price was great for the portions, but I doubt I'd go back.

KDzEZFxj47cehbTBCBe-Cw.text: I hate this place.In a few words: this is an expensive mediocre pizza, I mean seriously expensive. But they kind of take reservations, and if you want to have a pizza in a 2 hours timein soho this is one of the few places where you can have something decent. But ridiculously overpaid.This is a difficult-to-be-missed place, right in the center of Soho, with very big windows, and a queue outside. The personnel at the entrance is usually very kind, and as I said before the best part is that they kind of take reservations, in the sense that you ask for a table, they take your reservation and they send you an sms when the table is ready. Something that both Manca and Pilgrims (much better pizza places) don't, and whenever you are a big group this is something you need!But then... I mean pizza is kind of ok, a bit on the too fluffy for my taste but it's still an ok pizza, they have menabrea, a common beer in northern italy which seems a bit difficult to find around here, but the price is something that makes me super angry: a pizza+a beer + some shared olives comes around 30 pounds pp... I mean seriously, more than 40 Euros for a pizza! It's just ridiculous, nobody ever tried to set a price that is so high! damn you Princi, you do not deserve to stay in my pizza list!!

Tlm6jfw6EnCzfilJ-x2lNw.text: We came upon this place for brunch while we visited London. It's cafeteria style, but you can also have sit down service. We sat at a table on a Sunday morning and it was busy, so service was a little slow. I ordered the baked eggs; the tomato sauce with it was really delicious. Worth the wait if you have time. Or worth doing grab and go, as well. A little pricey, but good quality.

7w-qXwzeEJ4nYDH7r8NJzQ.text: Great breakfast, a favorite of locals and for good reason. We had a variety of foods and none of them disappointed!

WM9a1VZCnZL_5-c6NN1ATA.text: The food here was good, but service really wasn't on point. We were seated at a table but they switched is to sit by the pizza making place where there was ashes flying all over the table. When we asked for a discount they barely compensated us anything - when you come please make sure you're sitting at a table not by the cashier!

OWlcnyAf7_25QUJ6Kpsrig.text: Probably good for grabbing a piece of pizza to go but do not recommend sitting down for dinner. The service is poor. The food is mediocre and the music was terrible fir dinner. Not a good experience for us. Will not be back.

KZ3H4UyJBvm_eXrw4jXW_A.text: I'm a huge fan of this massive - and always busy - Italian deli. They serves up some extremely delicious items that are always freshly made with only the best ingredients. The staff is friendly, fast and always willing to guide you in the right direction concerning food. The prices are - however - high. That's a fact and you can find a proper sit-down meal in the area for same. It doesn't make the food at Princi any bad though, just expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

H-xEauIr6yKkfbthYfQRaQ.text: My husband and I scored a little table in the corner on a busy Thursday night with only a 5-10 minute wait. We were impressed with the array of cakes and pastries as you entered. Also, every server and hostess we interacted with were actually Italian, which was a good sign. We shared the prosciutto and fresh mozzarella appetizers, which was so fresh and delicious, I wouldn't be surprised if they have it flown in directly from Italy every day. We then split a pizza and the carbonara, plus a half bottle of wine. Everything was incredibly fresh and authentic, and reminded me of some of the best food I ate in Italy. Service was good, though the food took a little long to come out, I assume because it was very busy. We were too tired for desert, so instead we took a torte back to our hotel, and it was delicious. Definitely worth checking out next time we are in London.

EEI4vrqzt4_QPI4sWB_pSw.text: I like this place. I don't LOVE it but i like it and have gone more than once. (i went today) ^^It's almost always busy during normal peak hours~~ and people are going in and out constantly it seems like~~ as soon as you walk in...reservations are to your left (i've personally never made one) and the "line" is directly in front of you... You walk in and you basically kind of stand in line~~ Use good judgement if there's someone waiting....the reason for this is that it looks like a cafeteria lunch line...but if you're only getting desserts just walk in and stand by the desserts if you're getting food pass up the dessert people and stand near the food~ Can be kind of annoying and crazy when it's busy~ After paying for the food at the end of the "lunch line"...if you've paid for drinks you get them at the "bar".. which is at the very back of the entire place. Then you carry your tray and find a seat... Although it's always been busy when i've gone i never waited for a free spot. what i liked: 1. the salad (big plate = pick 4) (small= pick 2)2. the beef lasagna is good/ very cheesy and rich3. cakes were OK~ try the passion fruit cheese cake~ loved the tang of the passion fruit 4. Pizza OKI too~** I don't know what it is about this place~ maybe it's the all italian work crew that makes me feel like it's authentic? the food isn't amazing but i just like going here to people watch and i like the hustle and bustle of it~ This review may sound ambiguous but...i gave it 4 stars because it's just one of those places i like... just because.... and would go back again... just because~

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. The chocolate cake and passion fruit cheesecake were yummy~
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. My plate of salads~ mozerella balls~~

5fPUeQV0mSmfaaTvUKQduA.text: Possibly the best place I've been for breakfast globally. Very friendly staff, great fresh food, and top class choices to take something out for when you leave (nutella doughnuts are great!). Can't wait to go back.

5GWrDO-AcytBOvswNdVRIw.text: I had researched this restaurant before leaving for London and was pleased to find my expectations exceeded. I didn't know that the place would be so busy - I recommend making a reservation in advance. However, the very nice Maître d brought us menus while we waited in line behind the velvet like ropes at the front of the restaurant. As you are standing on the street in this odd line with the smell of bread and pizza wafting out the door you can't help but get excited for this place. The service was great, everyone was extremely helpful and nice. I asked a lot of questions and all of them were answered and suggestions were offered when I wasn't sure what to order.We got a table in the back corner of the sit down area (not the buffet area). While waiting for our food to arrive I snuck over to the buffet style area to order some extra pastries to take home. From the buffet area, I picked up a loaf of semolina bread, chocolate cookie, passion fruit cheesecake, and the black forest cake (recommended by the server). The passion fruit cheesecake was incredible. The square of punchy goodness was the perfect thing to eat as soon as we got back to our flat.After picking my way through the goodies at the bar, I went back to our table. We ordered the bruschetta (comes with tomato basil, olive tapenade, and aubergine), braesaola, rocket, and parmesan antipasti, and margherita pizza. I loved the pizza. The sauce was perfect, not to sweet not too tomatoey. The cheese on the pizza was very fresh and had a really nice flavor to it. We finished our meal off with three profiteroles. They were TO DIE FOR. YUM.*Edit - I forgot to add we also ordered the spaghetti carbonara which was pretty good as well. (I am really picky when it comes to carbonara and this almost lived up to my insane expectations)

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Semolina Bread
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Profiteroles
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. margherita

LqqMlDa2BzlS7Z_DSdoBnQ.text: With a fantastic spread of bread, pizza, cakes and salad to feast your eyes on, Primchi is destined to satisfy hunger and an appetite for variety and originality. It is also one of the rare places around Soho that can serve you quality food straight away which is such a rare commodity and much needed when you're in want of a quick dinner before going to the theatre. The Pizza Capricciosa I had was a bit tough but certainly filling with a good sprinkling of olives, ham, mushroom and mozzarella. The Rainbow salad was one of the nicest salads I ever remember having as there was a good range of different vegetables, such that I don't even know what they were, but they were indeed crunchy and appetising. The Pasta salad was very pleasant too with pesto, pine nuts and small bits of tomato in the mix. What looked like a 'scotch egg' was actually an Arancino di Riso (which tastes like lasagne in a breadcrumb fried crispy ball). Finally the chamomile tea was just what you would want; fresh, fragrant and refreshing. The downsides to Primchi is that the food is rather cold, the service a little haphazard as one long counter gives rise to inevitable confusion with where the queue begins and where it ends, and the seating is much like a canteen that is filled to the brim. Nevertheless, Primchi is great to have around; significant effort and attention to detail can be seen in all the food and drink and the infinite display on show is enough to tickle your taste buds at any time.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Cannolo
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Pizza Cappriciosa, rainbow salad and pasta salad
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Arancino Di Riso & Speck and Brie Pizza

XfdUiq2Ow0OF9Xb_CQfI7A.text: Great atmosphere, food and concept. You pick up as many dishes as you would like from savoury to sweet. The tea comes as loose leaf in a pot with unlimited refills. Lovely place to catch up with friends over lunch!

9vL0_2QO95fYHwS2ItYtrQ.text: Love these Italian bakeries / cafes that are so authentic right down to the Italian baristas and make you feel like you have been transported to a busy cafe in Milan. This place had great ambience and cakes. We had the blackberry tart and the pear/ chocolate cake with a latte - all very decadent, rich and Italian. Place was full and you may have to wait to get a table but creates a great ambience - will be back to try the food

WFgi83d25XqSNR8O5kaMuA.text: This latest addition to the vast range of Soho eateries only opened in Oct but is already a bit hit with the ex pat Italians and good food lovers. Their ethos is Spirito di Milano and it shows. From the tasteful understated Italian decor and the fabulous pizza, salads, cakes (made fresh on the premises), salads and the best coffee I have tasted in a long time, it is just wonderful. You sit at long tables, the prices are very reasonable and it is cash only. Already it is busy every night and will just get more popular. Go now while you can still get in. Enjoy.

1uincNA7u2BvaEL-QFWzvw.text: The pizza was similar to what you can get from a kebab shop. The croissant was over-cooked. The only thing I enjoyed there was the tomato mozzarella salad. The stuff is a little bit expensive, too. Usually Yau raises the prices of his restaurants after an introductory period. It's scary to think these prices are going to be even higher in the future. The staff doesn't speak good English and the ones who did, didn't know what a bunch of the dishes were named. Overall, I was very disappointed.

pVkYOkpH2KG8WIj0c9sMaA.text: difficult to find a sit when its lunch or dinner time! delicious Italian style desserts and pizze! also they have nice quality of coffee and few salads and warm foods.

zn-pttjhPhmRuu1iPDPV7Q.text: Good italian restaurant providing high quality food ranging from croissants, to pizza, tarts , salads, pudding , baked hot foods etc at a great value. Their wine list though is quite small. My favourite is their meaty lasagne and their pizzas made from distinctively north italian bread and covered with rich crescenza cheese and ham. Pizzas cost about 2.50 a slice. Lasagnes start from 6 quid.At princi, you order and collect your food from the counter and then try to find somewhere to sit hence the reason for only 4 stars as the only seating available is one long narrow central table which means that at peak hours its quite difficult to find somewhere to sit and enjoy your meal.

_cz_1155tANW4gUJraaikQ.text: A new eatery in Soho that is worth visiting. This is Alan Yau''s latest venture with an Italian Bakery chain. They sell a variety of breads, pastries, pizzas, and a number of hot food. Food quality is good, prices are affordable and location is great. Highly recommended.

OYLiZeJl0y1wjc1z8-iw9A.text: I like bread and I love Princi's bread and pastries. Went there 3 times and it's a great place to hang out with a couple of friends. We get a wide variety of food with just under £10. It's highly recommended when you just want a quick bite without compromising value.

9QWMlAufzWp2eBYvAmlRTw.text: Average priced takaway with great tasting food. The coffee is excellent.

UywBAmh_YV2uj0aR5kadoA.text: As my waistline slowly expands as does Princi's coffers. i cannot help but sit in Princi and feel that I am somewhere in the village of New York. The attention to detail in presentation and the incredibly high-quality food are rarely combined in London. If you like dough in all its forms then this is the place to go. The breads (fruit baguette - yum!), pizzas and sweets are all stunning. The cannoli (or what I would call a cannoli) are perfect little moments of custard pastry heaven, and at 80p each they are a bargain. Haven't had coffee or any drinks here, I am sure they are all good. One complaint, the water feature makes me feel like I am eating in Hakkasan's or Yauatcha's toilet. Think it detracts from the general Scandinavian womb-like quality of the rest of the place. Go eat!

NQI5sQJmAvtbmx9wBsULww.text: A hip, busy Italian cafeteria tucked in Soho, frequented by an odd mix of tourists, chic locals and designer-types, offering some surprisingly good food. Don't mind the crowds and enjoy a quick, fresh, delish lunch at one of the communal tables. Also great for coffee and heavenly desserts with friends in an upbeat environment. Prices are very reasonable.

nM-rDNqVcZGtWt8xmrh6GA.text: Lovely bakery with great food, cakes and bread. Busy place but definitely worth it

2omijFNmLi5uc82bgbSTRw.text: i walked past this restaurant several times while visiting london earlier this  month and i passed it up thinking it was only a bakery.  later in the week some friends suggested this place for lunch and my assumption was corrected.the seating is casual, and mostly at long tables (so you may well end up seated next to a stranger ... ).  there are a few tall "tables" where you can stand and take your meal if you decide you can't wait for a seat to become available.  we grabbed seats first and then organized food ...food is served buffet style, no significant waiting time (at least not for me).  the offerings are chock full of carbolicious goodness (i'm a type 2 diabetic and i wish i could have adequately planned for this but as i was on vacation i took one for the team).  very tasty pasta entrees ... my friends chose to have dessert and i forget what they had so i'll have to point it out in the dessert case next time i visit.  this is a very busy restaurant ... lots of people and lots of staff going here and there ... and *very* noisy.  this is not a place where you want to have a lunchtime meeting--you won't hear what's going on ... the woman seated next to me had planned to do this and was failing miserably.  so: plan to have a good time, but don't plan to do business here ... this isn't a starbucks.also: their gents washroom is easily among the top 10 nicest restrooms i've ever used in a public place.  i would definitely go here again.  bring friends, and have a great time!

530WzPw5qqUCDOdD3G_zXw.text: popped in here for dinner with some pals.  my friend recommended as she works in the area and was intrigued by the open space and hustle bustle of it all.  there's a doorman, which is funny for a buffet like set up.  luckily we were able to snag a table as two couples got up to.  for a space so big, i'm surprised that there isn't more seating.  there are high tops where a few can stand and eat.  suppose it's better for digestion?  i went ahead and got the salad platter for £7.50, which i picked the chicken apple and avacado salad, bow tie tuna pasta and some roasted pumpkin.  i enjoyed the chicken, but was a bit creamy.  the bow tie pasta was quite al dente.  the food was filling, and the food was good enough, but not stellar.  also, thought it was strange that i had to pick up my beer from the bar separate form paying for my meal.overall, interesting space and some tasty food stuffs.

bC4xtQ2qLzBYRXmTIECKHg.text: Excellent thin crust pizza, great wine selection and really tasty lemon cake! Food was creative and service was outstanding!

KRByzZrNtzbXQqSeFx9lVA.text: Simple really; the foods great, though loaves aren't cheap, but the service sucks.And that's putting it very politely.I'd give more detail but I'm getting pissed off just thinking about the frustrations of getting served here.

vnBFVH-tepmw89SfI4mHBA.text: YUM! I scarfed down a piece of ham and cheese pizza here between pubs and it was pretty fantastic - will definitely be back to try it properly. There was a nice buzzy atmosphere around 9pm but we were served quickly and the pizza slices were packed into little trays and paper bags, making them very portable. Can't wait to return.

henT3C7w39KSyvuQk0giaw.text: i went here with some london locals - really loved it!really good food and nice atmosphere. from what i understand the restaurant is a part of a chain with another in Milano - so there were a good crowd of italians there. i got a slice of there pizza a brownie and their strawberry juice , as well a cream filled tube like pastry - all very good. i wouldnt go expecting a filling meal but if u like a busy atmosphere with great design and delicious food its a must go!enjoy!

y0BdN3VoPNHs5r-5a72AcA.text: If I could add more stars, I would.  This place is awesome and you can get real Italian food for really reasonable prices.  The best is the authentic Italian men walking around serving appetizer trials.  :)

MdRcBa3Ii5ayh7fOblUeUQ.text: This location is ideal for post-theatre snacking as long as you stick to the savories and avoid the overwhelmingly sweet desserts and surprisingly weak cappuccino. Ordering your food can be somewhat chaotic - people seem to gather at the counter en masse rather than wait in an orderly queue - and once you've paid it can be tricky finding seats together at  the communal tables or along the rear wall of water during peak hours (which seem to be all day, every day). The aubergine parmigiano and zucchini fritters and cauliflower in bechamel sauce were excellent, but the bland tiramisu and dry pistachio cheesecake with a very sour berry topping were major disappointments. Prices are remarkably low, especially for this area.

WrCHY7Tjf3Yk7PXO36oFng.text: Great bustling place that serves heavenly desserts, fresh bread, yummy salads and miscellaneous dishes. Its operates on a self service basis, which makes it really hard to get seats when you're alone and the restaurant is packed (usually). During non peak hours its a nice place to catch up with a friend over coffee. Very centrally located as well. Must try: Lemon chocolate toffee cake! Absolutely heavenly.

M_X7aUGi0_0por42a2Xngw.text: This is a funny place. Imagine the English confronted to a big dilemma: queuing when there's no queue in sight and no system clearly identified. Indeed in this modern Italian bakery there's no other way to order your croissants or lasagna than to grab someone's attention. You'd better bag seats first, then go and order the food. After ordering you're supposed to go to the bar where you pay for everything. Service is quick but not impatient. All the waiters are Italian and this adds to the charm of the place. There are not many seats. People stand and eat at the same time at small tables made of granite and porphyry. There are also seats along the back wall where water is constantly flowing. Along the counter you can choose what you fancy among the varieties of bread, salads, pasta, pizza slices and pastries(I can only talk about pastries. We had a Millefeuille starwberry, a chocolate cake, a glass of red wine and an expresso: all delicious). It's not very expensive and suits perfectly to a late breakfast or a pre-meal. Princi is an Italian that exists already in Milano and has been imported by the Alan Yau, the restaurateur. It's a joint venture, not his own project but this is a refreshing addition to Soho's restaurant scene. It's hip but not pretentious. It's about sharing, sharing food with friends and space with the other customers. It's also an interesting architectural experience.

r91pY_pIKqu171lWm7Ly9A.text: This review is just for the coffee and pastries. Cappucino is OK; pastry stuff is OK. A fun place to chat with friends and grab a quick bite. f you can find a seat..alwats crowded.

zas5oidJfJwQ8EBE7t8-VA.text: I spend little time in the centre of town, more trying to avoid it in fact. So this special journey was really special- destination: princi Italian Bakery on Wardour Street. My friends are raving about it, my mother is raving about it, lordy! everyone is raving about it. And here's why. Bread is bread right? Nope- not when it stops you in your tracks. Try the soft fresh bread sticks laden with green olives. That's all I need say. It's good, it's so good. I could tell you about the boutique interior, full to overflowing with hungry punters, the great coffee and the choices of fresh pizza and pasta. But best you just go see for yourself and add your rave review to this already long list.

OJe8LTFJW17jcEcLMNEQMw.text: Very very busy almost all the time, but service is normally quick and food is lovely. Will take a while to find a spot to sit and enjoy though.

6B3eqpOxCyhqYRNroo4jrQ.text: Great value, busy place for brunch or a light evening meal on the go in the heart of Soho. I was initially drawn in by the sight of the fantastic range of cakes. Be warned can be very busy on a Saturday afternoon when competition for seating can be intense.

cclkTCOHqySKhUX5Z6eOLw.text: This place is just wonderful. It's really relaxed (no booking required), bustly, all the staff are Italian and it's just got a lovely atmosphere. Food-wise, it's spot on too - fantastic breads, cakes, lasagne, aubergine parmigiana, gnocchi and the first time I went there I spent less than a tenner on two of us. What more could you want?

2vKhRA1cdfX3NsSKi6a45w.text: Love Princi concept,decor,food - especially the spinach & Ricotta mini pastry bites,only the Pizza slices i do not think are that great - but then i am fussy about Pizza.Only downside: getting a seat can be tricky.

OUWeo-yY0NAB6as51yUSHw.text: Great cakes and mini buns  perfect to go with the decent coffee. Huge long counter with lots of treats on view and the baking is all in open view, so you can see what they are putting in and taking out of the huge ovens. Service is a bit hit and miss but the place is well worth a visit if you're in Soho.

dH4qiObhea09kUtgPqB2fg.text: Five star canoli from this trendy place!  We came for dessert but I wish I had sampled the pizza and pasta.  Lots of non-English Europeans populated this place, and I mean lots!  I consider that a good sign.  The canoli was great as was the espresso (esp shot was kinda small but they usually are :-)  It has been a long time since I have had canoli this good!  Prailine chocolate cake was okay and the chocolate brownie was only okay too.  Neither of the two chocolate items was intense enough for my taste.  Many of the patrons were there to socialize in groups of friends, so be prepared to hunt for a space and then be cozy and friendly with your neighbors (and stand up as table space was limited --they do have table space but if you want to sit, come during off-peak hours).  A spritzer made from Proseco, Aperol, and club soda was all the rage (see photo); seemed a bit overpriced for 7.5£ --I would rather spend my ££ on espresso and canoli.....  In summary, if you are looking for a dessert Mardi Gras, this is your place!

Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Cocktail menu
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Fabulous cannoli and praline desert, with espresso

MG0fbM97-RRIR_PkRpiDLA.text: Ummm the pain chocolate is to die for. Melt in your mouth delicious. A great latte presented in a juice glass (interesting). Cute place with a lot of italian pastries and treats.

Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Latte and pain chocolate

EuCEOtsZ0dk_bC95qRZa4Q.text: A okay place to have a pizza. The vibe is okay. Maybe a bit pricy but overall a good service.You might have to wait but they will call you when it is time for your table and have it booked for 5 minutes. A good time for a cocktail here or somewhere nearby.

7auBld-11pB0VRCv2KqhDw.text: Absolutely wonderful staff and delicious selection of Italian sandwiches, entrees, and pastries. Ended up here two nights in a row for dinner - incredible!

YnVXpEOr1_abFJ9y0Ns5cg.text: If you want to have a quick meal with no quality go there.. I had chicken and there was a peace of plastic. Drinks like coffee and such are available ..The best thing for Muslims that they have Halal food.

mmMYJR9I7f04HLYvL23UjA.text: The upscale cafeteria concept doesn't seem to have taken hold in any major way in the States (at least not in my neck of the woods), and maybe it hasn't really done so in the UK either.  But Prinzi sure seems to fill a void.  Largely Eye-talian in persuasion, surprisingly healthy and easy on the wallet, it effectively gussies up an all-too-often lowbrow concept.  And it shows that it's not hard to do, AND to make it fashionable--quite a contrast from the usual cafeteria in the States, which all too often attracts the demographic who dines at 16:30 and is in bed promptly at 20:00.  I was especially taken by the sides--and what cafeteria can ever succeed without terrific sides?--particularly the steamed green beans.The one criticism is that the place apparently recently expanded in size....but didn't grow the toilet facilities in proportion to the size.  Didn't grow them at all, really.  They're nice and clean enough.  But a stylish place like this shouldn't need to have queues 10 people long.  Looks like this'll be a pretty difficult fix too!  Oh well, it's a cafeteria: you shouldn't need to linger long enough to...uh...what's the English slang-of-the-day for "to pee"?

5FuTNnTxG8STaeNe2Gu9Bw.text: I want to like it. hell I want to love it. I mean, I love Wardour Street, home to some of my favourite eats for many a decade.But when you pay near £4 for a slice of pizza I'm not sure I can. I think I should go there for certain pastries but I'm a sucker for trying out a slice, but I prefer Maletti nearby or Icco over in Fitzrovia which you can get a whole pizza for same price. I didn't think much of the taste either. Wasn't knock your socks off awesome.Also didn't like that the seats are so so close. Not really feeling this place which is a shame because I was certain I would.

2LziP_fLTJjKZ9SSHnZsqQ.text: It's more grapple than Grappa in here! Surrounded by the running water feature in Princi, it rather created a calm or in my case counteracted the cacophonous din in this food-hall, sorry fighting arena where diners, usually decent folk- I'm sure, have to tussle for a chance to get a place to sit at a table all-whilst clutching a tray. So use the flowing feature to wash your hands, or your mouth out, as getting a table needs fighting talk. It's no good if there's a school of you, you'll never get to eat together. You'll be split into pairs and I warn you, one of you'll have to stand guard of your place whilst the other queues for food and on their return, repeat this process yourself. Princi creates the frustrating feeling of what it must be like in a fishtank. Like a fish in a tank in Seaworld. Except this glass tank we were behind; the long stretch of window where greasy passing Soho noses press up against the cold panes, see a brightly floodlit hectic scrabbling Milanese-like scene, but diners clutch trays, scrumming for tables like sharp nosed sharks at feeding time. Although bright lights bounce off of the glossy coral red Romanesca topped tray bakes, shiny strawberry cheesecakes and gently glinting merengue topped lemon pavlovas it quite highlights what else could be up for grabs in this open area. One cannot deny Pelici is a Soho showpiece; a showstopper of a shopfront, but diners prowling for tables aren't the only ones lurking in the depths of soho. There are thieves stalking their prey, peeping in from the windows of Princi too, waiting for opportunities to squeeze in between the crush. On a Friday evening it was impossible. The pool side life guard on the door simply couldn't attend to security and also had to run around the floor as a makeshift waiter.  Once again, there could be pick-pocketers pouncing whilst you go back up, buffet style to pick your pudding. Also with the doors open to all and sundry, I was cold and so was my dinner. So with chills, multiplying, I'm serious. That entrance, is as much of a security threat as are the cakes are for your health, so watch your bags if you're not watching your waist line.

Oneao-MBKDpbiMETAeGwBQ.text: My boyfriend and I ordered two pizzas from here on Friday night, delivered by UberEats. As we ate the pizzas, my boyfriend bit down on a piece of GLASS that was in the pizza. We called the restaurant to let them know. They didn't even apologise, told us to contact UberEats and hung up.Would NOT recommend you eat here as the customer service is a disgrace and they clearly do not have any health and safety standards.

2an1k-VadGbaL6JVW23SgQ.text: Summary: + GREAT food AND DESSERT+ Spacious and chic ambience + Order at the counter, which also serves as food display+ Follow the sight of food, follow your heart + But remember, your eyes are bigger than your stomach + It gets very busy. So be ready to elbow your way in to find a spot Overall: Located in the heart of Wardour Street, this gorgeous Italian deli café is one of my favourite places in SOHO. They have freshly baked breads, steaming hot pizza, salad bar, hot main dishes and great cakes. In other words, they have EVERYTHING. From outside, the place looks like a chic hotel restaurant. The interior does not betray your expectation. The dusky brightness of brass tables somehow matches the white marble walls and dark stone floor. The combination gives this large dining space a tasteful refinement without being glitzy. The place is apparently called Princi. I can never remember what it is called. The place is too stylish to have a big banner of their name at the back of the counter. The only branding they have outside the restaurant is very small and the fancy swirly font makes it impossible to decipher what is written. So when I refer to this place, I am usually forced to use rather unsophisticated descriptions such as "that big posh Italian place in SOHO". Hopefully, writing a review will help me remember the name of this charming café. Anyway, the place was as busy as usual when I went in for a dessert break. (I seem to do that a lot these days.) I often see one or two creative types with their laptops (mostly Mac) here but there were none of them that day. God knows what those people do for their lives I joined the group of people who are forming a kind of "organic" queue that you see in good old British pub. When I felt I had waited for a sufficient amount of time as a courtesy, I attracted an attention of one of the servers at the cake section and ordered Cremoso alla fragola (layered berry mousse cake).  Food: This three-layered delight came in the shape of a fluffy strawberry mousse sandwiched by a thin sheet of mixed berry jello on top and moist sponge at the base. The little bits of fresh berries in the top jello layer enhance the airy texture of the cake. I like the way all the elements worked together without one dominating another.  One other thing to mention is their toilet smells incredible. They have some sort of lemon grass incense that fills the private space with heavenly fragrance. That said, I have only been to male toilet. So I can't speak of female one. I only went there for a tea this time but they also have great food and bakery section. Maybe I will review them next time.

3HcsWRzJ-E24oQx8hy9wSg.text: Their pizza was pretty decent. They did have many options. The place was packed and we felt very rushed by the servers so they could get in the next group of people.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Quattro farmagio was my favorite

omQl1XkkdNtr_gJpct1v8g.text: Good pizza, fresh salads, nice desserts, nice place to just pop into and have a quick bite with a friend. We pop into Princi often either before or after Evening College at Hillsong in the Dominion Theatre. Very refreshing after a long day at work and an evening at class! Great for students or after work meal!

lcHy0ITy99tp9XpAVLOjJg.text: I just love this place because of the variety and freshness of the food here. Its cafeteria style, meaning que up and pick yo foods. I've eaten here a few times, the salads are good. The pizzas are meh, the main dishes are good but I come here now for the chocolate brownie. Oh man is it good, they also have these croissant looking things that have cream spilling out but its really a  brioche with a lemon cream. Its super delish with a cup o' tea.

wvQGLWBEfbv8zuYbqebL9Q.text: Flew into London late in the evening, grabbed some dinner and found this place thru yelp for dessert. We arrived around 11:30pm and the place was jam packed. Every dessert we ordered was delicious. The one that stood out the most to me was the lemon chocolate toffeeBonus for tourists, FREE WIFI! Traveling internationally, Fast free internet is a precious commodity.
