Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

fUtzKzBaPq6E5u2qbzkIaQ.text: Came here for dinner with my cousin one night, and it was quite busy. The right side of the restaurant is self serve, and the left side is table service. This restaurant is quite large, but it was pretty crowded. When I first walked in, I was quite distracted from huge display of desserts and pastries they had! They all look decadent. I waited for a table for about 10 minutes. The table space was quite cramped, since I could barely get to my table. We ordered the antipasto to share, and I ordered the spaghetti with pancetta, and my cousin ordered the meat pizza. The appetizer came quickly, and there was a good selection of meats. The entrees took quick awhile to come. The server did tell me that the spaghetti takes a little longer, maybe because they're making it extra fresh for me?! Well, both entrees finally came. The spaghetti was good, but a little on the salty side because of the pancetta. I really enjoyed the sauce, and the pasta was cooked very well.Princi is very affordable, especially if you're coming from the U.S., and you are use to cheap food and big portions. They give a good amount of food without breaking your wallet. The only problem is service. I understand that service may not be a big thing here, but I shouldn't have to ask 5 times to the same person for water! I also took a few desserts home after, and they were delicious! Princi is one of the better meals I've had in London, so far.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Spaghetti & pizza
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Antipasto for two

EM1w3Wa6v5aF9oprRV9hLA.text: The desserts here are really amazing, especially the cannoncini. It usually sells out before the afternoon so go earlier if you can. I wouldn't recommend the ready-made food here as it sits out all day and tastes quite stale.

7Blc40KTe-f5FdeGZF_lnw.text: Such a beautiful restaurant ... the wooden oven pizza is amazing .... bakery and cakes are so yummy plus staffs are very helpful and polite. Highly recommend it.

VIKh-buJHSBVfN64xwAwaQ.text: The best tiramisu ever.. So light and fluffy ! The canolli has a perfect crunchy outer but the cream inside is a bit too sweet for my taste!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

nKrx3SnohyjKXdF4DoKhSA.text: You know you're in an authentic Italian place when two simple ingredients make a delicious meal.The focaccia is crispy, the Parma ham the right cut. You really don't need anything else.I love this place, it makes me feel at home, also thanks to a good espresso at the counter and small talk with the friendly Sicilian barista.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Focaccia con crudo

6yWXmaAImyOo-nD6_uUNYg.text: Princi is a swarmed Italian place with a massive selection of salads and pastas. Dessert section also takes up significant counter space.Get here early and be ready to bump elbows with your neighbors since it gets so crowded there's a security guard to control the traffic in and out of the place.Not too pricey for that part of London.

1MC900zIv9XXD-r5jGgXxA.text: Good value for money. I've only ordered online so can't say what the restaurant itself is like. But the Chicken Milanese with roasted plum tomatoes and potatoes and steamed spinach for £8.50 is a steal and very well done.

VF2A8lrrRjttJ0vXLvZzFg.text: Quick review:+ great pitstop over food+ delicious Italian "snacks"+ recently expanded in sizeFull review:I've been coming to Prini for a couple of years and it used to be about half the size so you would have to wait around for tables with eagle-eyes, spotting potential leavers and swoop in for the space. It's still pretty busy last time I went on a Saturday lunch time but we were able to get a table for two quite easily. They have expanded with what looks like a restaurant so perhaps people are booking ahead instead of chancing it. On the more casual side, you get a wonderful selection of Italian food, from pizza and fresh salads to the mouthwateringly enticing pastries and cakes. The staff at the counter is really friendly and bubbly, happy to take time and explain the food in front of you (especially if they have no or unhelpful labels). The staff that mills around the floor are eager to take your empty plates away as soon as you have finished indulging yourself, undoubtedly hinting you ought to move on. It's not somewhere you can stay very long at peak period, otherwise you get hungry diners glaring at you, hoping to get your table. But it is a wonderful place to catch up with a friend over some good food beyond your everyday sandwiches and baguettes.

jOgheQnM3gumb3v4ef3MGA.text: The spot has this amazing Italian feel to it that makes the experience of eating here truly remarkable. Everything is delicious - the pizzas are amazing and a constant choice for lunch in my mind; the sweets are even more amazing and I just love the Princi tiramisu. I will surely return for more but that's understandable since I've already come back so many times.

cmN4poxmciFzIipQThbsoQ.text: Praise the the holy foodie gods for finally blessing me with a place in UK that prepared a meal that pleased every ion in my foodie soul! While on a search for my fixation sushi in London I stumbled across Princi and instantly fell in love. It's the kind of the place you don't mind coming to alone as you can sit in the window and people watch while you enjoy a meal. (Simply speaking from my personal experience) The pizza is what you must come for, grab a fork, a knife, and simply go to town. Gave me the feeling of being in Italy while in the UK. Clean the palate with a glass of Pinot Grigo and you will be set to see the sights of Soho. Glad I have a few more days in the UK as I'll be back again for sure!

pMOQ4oyDUc8Ex5yJSwQ7YQ.text: Best Pizza in Soho and I tried them all.Always order takeaway as the whole "everyone can see me eat" vibe of the restaurant design with the see through windows and cafeteria style tables are not for me.The deserts are okay though more recommend the Italian food on hot tables.

YtqJnEt9qHdVwj-QNuHL4w.text: Only had the passionfruit cheesecake but it was amazing. The reason it's 4 stars and not 5 is because I felt that the dessert was a bit overpriced at £5 but would've been more accurately priced at £3.

pXHGIZEKaq20RfXcuhuzvg.text: This place is great on all levels...starting with the food...it's awesome. The prices are very reasonable. The staff could not be nicer and more accommodating. They offer table service, cafeteria style service and take out. It gets real busy on the weekends. And they are open late. I highly recommend giving Princi a try. I tried a chicken cutlet with potatoes and veggies. Also tried the Sicilian pizza, cheese and salami and Gorgonzola. Also had the prosciutto sandwich. All very good.  I removed a star from my original review. Had dinner there last night (oct 5) The food was fabulous, but the service was absolutely awful. In fact I don't think I could have been worse if they tried. I would highly recommend the cafeteria side and skip the dining room . I was quite surprised and disappointed.

YpxBbzQ2dLfo1BE1gHPwEA.text: I paid this place a late night visit this week. I would say that Princi is one of the most appealing looking places to come in Soho from the exterior. Every time I walked past... I felt the magnetic pull. This time it managed to suck me and my companion in!So really we were looking for some late drinks and snacks, and we were not disappointed. Broccoli, beetroot, ham & cheese and ricotta & spinach pastries, cannolis and a huge slice of cheesecake... all washed down with sambuca! I would rate this place as highly inside as on the outside. A good amount of money and effort has been put into making this place look amazing. Even the toilets were well designed. Staff here were very helpful and eager to help, but I do feel that they are hampered by their awkward till system. It was painful for both them and me to finish the actual transaction.Overall, a decent place. The only reason that it does not rate higher is that the food was pretty poor value for money.NB I was just about to post this as 3 stars.... but I forgot the evening doorman. He earns the place an additional star! Really. He was that good! Polite and respectful at all times - he really brought personality to the place. Give the man a pay rise!

alMgVwe_709Q3941HLmT-g.text: I can easily imagine how this place can be a bit or a nightmare during lunch or dinner "rush hour", but we found Princi to be a safe haven after a late night meeting on a Monday night.The food looked and smelled lovely but we decided to just pop in for a quick drink. The service was impeccable and we soon decided to stay for another, and if they hadn't closed at midnight we'd still be there.Not sure if Princi is authentically Italian or not, but it certainly has a mediterranean feel to it. I loved everything about it and will return as soon as possible to sample some of their food.

sMtOyprZISYz02zELXuqPw.text: Princi is pretty good overall. I love the space (although cannot understand why, given all the giant space and many many customers, there is only one female toilet) and the rows and rows of delicious looking food. It's also cool that there is a waiter service section of the restaurant if you want something a bit more formal. I really liked the Princi breakfast - the sausage wasn't that great but the bacon was well cooked, the sourdough toast was a great accompaniment and the cannellini beans in tomato sauce had a rich flavour which enhanced everything else. The scrambled eggs were good too, although I actually ordered fried! Which brings me to the service which was very polite but a bit inattentive at times, although it was nice not to be rushed. Overall though, I think this is a great Soho spot.

_WI1iiC0X4W0O8jnM4v46w.text: Walking into Princi is like walking into a really Italian section of the Harrods food hall. It's really busy, it's really pretty and everything is a little bit expensive. The water feature on the back wall throws calming ripples of light against the wall, which is a hilarious counterpoint to the frenzy of customers and staff you'll encounter at peak times.The similarities with Harrods end there, though. Unlike the famous Food Hall, everything here is actually worth the price of admission. Honestly, choose something at random and you'll have a good time in this place. Everything is prepared in house, with the baked items being cooked in their wood-fired oven and therefore being extra awesomely tasty. Their salads are fantastic and you can mix and match them in a box for a good lunch. Their hot meals look good, but I'll be honest and say I've never tried them - I never get far enough into the shop before something else catches my eye!They've also recently added a small pizzeria section. Their pizzas are again cooked in the wood fired oven and while they're a little bready to be considered 'proper Italian' pizzas, they're very, very good. My personal fave is the D.O.C, loaded with cherry tomato wedges, buffalo mozzarella and fresh basil leaves - basically a margarita turned up to eleven.What's great about this place is that it's open early for breakfast and stays open until late, making it a great venue for a quick bite to eat after a trip to the theatre or concert on a friday night. It does get busy, but this just adds to the mad Italian charm of it all.

v1GNDjrr5Hjz6X_uBjw5Jg.text: I had the worst pizza of my life on the restaurant side. The crust was both soggy and burnt. The cheese was chewy. I would have sent it back but we were with our young child so time was of the essence an his tastes are not discerning. Go there for coffee or pastries. Don't go to the restaurant for pizza.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. All the bottom of the pizza was this burnt. Here you see the bottom of the crust.
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Soggy pizza burnt on the bottom.

R6VRoa8bZFBHJCmS-lLaDA.text: If only more restaurants could be like Princi. Unpretentious with a laid back atmosphere you'd be forgiven to expect that with no bookings taken and a first come first seated setup that the food would fall short of Soho's many fine eateries. However the food here is second to none. From the salads & pastas to the hot dishes and cakes, everything is wonderfully authentic Italian including the staff and half of the customers. Perfect for a first date over wine and cake this is my favourite place in London.Quick tip: when you arrive send your other half to find the seats whilst you grab the food. You'll thank me!

mIhHv1NBgKEmTaG32eqdgg.text: Stop for diner last night after theatre, food so so, ambiance really Italian and cool, to pricy for what you have.

4E6Xvl5xVECRZvzEdYSf5w.text: I wish they had this bakery/restaurant in LA. LA lacks in good bakeries. Anyway going back to my review for this place, it was my second time here. First time was a few years ago when I still lived in London. Second visit was on a Wed night last week. Both times it was very crowded but it's definitely worth the wait. Everything from the desserts, bakery items to the pizza served in the main restaurant area was great. So authentically Italian! Even all the staff in here seem to be from Italy. And you hear a lot of Italian (language) spoken amongst the clientele too. I guess it is a good thing this place is far from home as I will be a fat b*tch eating so many good desserts. Yum.

M56vpP1dwXL5PGjxFxITpA.text: I was introduced to this restaurant by a fellow Seattleite. Located between Soho and Leicester Square, it's a great spot for some delicious Italian food. They have a large selection of baked goods, flat breads and pastas. Their wine list isn't overly priced, and the service is excellent (it also helps that quite a few of their servers are beautiful men and women).Finding a seat can be difficult, but I highly recommend grabbing a perching spot before ordering at the counter.

rc9N2K0DI-ubgIbN1_7LGg.text: Go to spot for cakes and lunch.The sweets are brilliant: pear and chocolate cake, flour-less chocolate cake, the tiramisu are among my favorites.The salads are great: my favorites are the pumpkin and the aubergine.The pizzas are delicious.Amazing consistency--the food is great every time!

_RQFiRtjsyNdgKhJ0OpcLA.text: I'm having withdrawals already.Maybe because the baker in the window made looking bread so tempting.  Or maybe it was the amount of people that made the place look so worthwhile.  Or perhaps it was cause I just got off a 10 hour plane ride and was starving my ass off in Soho.Either way, my boyfriend couldn't have made a better choice for our first lunch in London.  The sandwiches here are so fresh, you'll forget you're eating in a restaurant.  I was waiting for my cousin (who works literally next door to this place at MPC. Lucky guy.) and was starving, and noticed the line out the door.  Surprisingly because of the system they have (with pointing to your food and paying at the end of the counter, finding your table and ordering wine in a separate area) works like magic, that you're in and eating this deliciousness within no time.I ordered an antipasto sandwich with fresh arugula and basil, fresh tomatoes, and fresh mozzarella inside a ciabatta bread.  OMFG. Boyfriend ordered the pizza margherita, which absolutely melted in your mouth.  Top it off with some Pellegrino water, you're good to go!  Absolutely a great place to go if you're in the mood for a quick snack, or if you're in with some friends to catch up over wine.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

X2o0ZDTFaAWzvvCMPobHfw.text: Two sides! The right is "buffet" style in terms of ordering your food right the counters and waiting to seat yourself. Left side is sit down "dinner" style. Wait in a line outside and yes, watch everyone inside eat their pizza. Delicious! Good wine and lots of desserts at the bakery.

JD3ARCtr-z5SQ-7GUEY-5w.text: I had breakfast here and it was amazing! Very high quality food. Loved the smoked salmon. Will be back soon!

-ZZTbtwOGfSCTaKy8bt8Ww.text: Love the place but don't love the prices. It is a small portion with the price you paid. It set in the middle of wardour street, a lot of happening at Soho end. The cakes always look yummy and i always tempted to try out different cakes. Good interior design..a sense of open space with good lighting and background music. Always find crowded in this place..Good things is they always give some free italian pizza to bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

U9051EqRSzCUpgnBidNfIA.text: Princi quickly became one of my favorite lunch places and they also had some of the best chocolate cakes I have ever had. I tried the gnocchi one, went for the sallads, you can choose different sallads so you get a little of everything. The pizzas are also great, i like the options that you can combine your food however you want, a little bit of this and that and it doesnt cost much. Only downside is that It's not that charming to sit there and eat as it gets really loud during lunchtime.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

T0oocywUwYnOQiT0-lepxA.text: Princi has amazing service considering its super casual order at the counter and take your number.  Food was very good as well.  Delicious soft scrambled eggs with toast and avocado.  Amazing pancetta and egg croissant.  Much better cappuccino and breakfast than Cote across the way. I was super amused by a french guy insisting to be served sitting at the window counter when its obviously an order at the display/register type place.  He orders 4 instead of two eggs scrambled.  His meal arrives its obviously more that 2 eggs and he proceeds to complain his order is missing the additional eggs.  The manager checks with the chef who confirms what was served.  The customer disagrees and they fire 2 more eggs for him.  I guess the customer is always right. (This guy was so wrong on all levels but I digress.) Super impressed with the service. A++

Gqo6MFFuYKhd5NF-dBVl4Q.text: Best pizza with giant mounts of buffalo mozzarella. Other good things of note : raspberry cheesecake, pain au chocolate, and breakfast of toast, avocado and poached egg. It's a great place whatever you're in the mood for. Quick breakfast on the go? Check. Sit in for a cocktail and nice meal? Check. Dessert and wine? Check. Slice of pizza and a salad? Check. You can even choose between table service or ordering at the counter.

s2tY_OMREqgIBrNab6JKAA.text: My friends love this place and I can see why - sort of. But for me, it really doesn't tick many boxes.One things, it so busy and chaotic. People are milling around constantly looking for seats. You have to move your seat to let them pass every few minutes which gets tiresome. The food is good but when it's so busy - I just order the easiest and quickest thing to eat so have only had the pizza and cheese pastry things. One day maybe I'll try some pasta.Anyway, what I mean to say is Princi is okay. The food is okay but it's just to fill my tum and not for me to rave about how delicious it was.

0dflRUNWFMcPNtq3Ub9THQ.text: We ate at the restaurant which was ok, but it looked like the prepared foods were more delicious. I wish I had tried the amaretto, pumpkin, and mascarpone salad.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Mussels
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Coffee: AMAZING

KoDk9wOYjonv4l4HmqDEcA.text: Decent food but terrible (often no) service. Avoid if you are short on time. Gail's, across the street, is faster, better, and more fun.

5jfN24k5K5UI_ydUqLpJKg.text: Came here to get a meringue the size of soccer ball. It was supposed to taste like raspberry, however, it just tasted like a vanilla meringue. Mildly disappointing but nothing to affect this review. It's mostly a sit and sip and some pastries. Fair prices and good customer service.

vy5paSon_qcEb15k-rTyWg.text: When you enter, you are welcomed by the nicest doorman. You have the option of sitting down and ordering from the menu or ordering from their cafeteria style, ready to go meal options. We decided to sit and order, the space was bit pinched, but intimate. Great decor and lighting. I ordered the margherita pizza, which consisted of tomato sauce, basil, mozzarella and parmesan for £5.50. The price was right. Once you've ordered, you can see two Italian guys, in the middle of the restaurant, tossing pizza dough in the air and having fun. Loved it! The pizza looked amazing when it arrived. The crust was perfectly crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside. It was thin crust, which is the best for Italian pizza, but the sauce was too saucy and made the crust slightly soggy in the middle. The flavours was good. I just wished the sauce was slightly thicker. They have lots of other options on their menu that I wouldn't mind trying next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Margherita

xt_uZA1I2GpubgzkllEelw.text: One of my lovely spots to grab lunch or if i am in central London shopping, Variety of food and best of all is the desert. ( deserts can be made from PORK  Gelatine i will recommend you to ask before buy)Staff can be temperamental now and again, previous managers were very professional, recent guys not as great as

fPiV5l63dF3Z7VxBQLwSig.text: One of the best places in Soho for pizza, once you've finished queuing up for about 15/20 minutes.  There's some herbs in the thin crust dough but they never give away the ingredient. Tastes amazing. Everything else on the menu is standard. They used to do a cheese and tomato croissant but don't seem to have that. Prices are fairly reasonable for the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

7C-0gghjRz2sczF4f-UoXg.text: This modern Italian has a nice laid-back atmosphere thanks to the self-service and the long tables but the interior design and the quality of the food give it a classy, elegant feel at the same time. There's also an à la carte seating area but we went for dessert only, so we didn't have to queue and found some free seats quickly. We shared two slices, one Tiramisu and one Passion Fruit Cheesecake. The Tiramisu didn't impress me at all because I could only see and taste cream and cocoa but no coffee and amaretto. The other slice was better, although it tasted nothing like your regular cheesecake but rather like Solero Exotic. As that's one of my favourite ice creams, I wasn't complaining. I also ordered a single espresso which was the best I had in a while! Unfortunately I don't know what kind of coffee they use.I'll probably go back to try their savoury offers next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Passion Fruit Cheesecake and Tiramisu on display
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. A super smooth espresso

0qrbe85hDNYA3VOeuwTGhQ.text: Seems to be a victim of it's own success.  Service was poor, but in defense of the waitstaff it just seemed like they were underprepared for the number of people they were trying to serve.Went here for a casual dinner with friends and expected a wait since it was a busy Saturday night.  The food was good (tasty Nduja sausage pizza with lots of spicy kick and a chewy crust!) and a good value (no mains more than 13), but not enough positives to counteract the poor service.  Some lowlights: - while waiting, 3 times being summoned by the hostess saying they were ready for us, only for us to have to wait still longer.  We were ready to accept the wait so don't tell us it's ready until you're sure it is!- being brought out our appetizers before any of our drinks- one main being brought out to the table 15 minutes before the other 2 mains- after waiting the 15 minutes, one main was wrong.  When I ordered, the waitress has corrected my pronunciation of the dish that I pointed to, so I know she heard me :)Probably best to visit during a non-rush time.  The quality and variety of pastry on offer looked very good, so perhaps it's earned a chance for a do-over from me.

utzh__5-t7gofB9sIR_Fkw.text: As a sworn lover of Italian food I'd have to say the bread these guys bake is squisito. A delightful chewy and moist crumb and then it was filled with olives that instead of have been soaked in vinegar etc. had been in olive oil. It made all the difference.The interior provided at busy yet down to earth atmosphere in the molto italien styled room.The cakes looked fantastic!===Disclaimer; this was a stop on a SoHo food safari-thing, so the review may seem rather slim but we only had a few items.

AjCWeRCkp97B28OvsgkSvA.text: Went here around 10 am to get a quick breakfast. The cappuccino's are great here! We ordered a plain croissant, a fruit salad (generous portion) and a croissant with scrambled eggs and pancetta (really tasty). All the other pastries looked really good as well! The only small letdown was that service wasn't the fastest, but the staff was friendly.

G-qmv5coISiYeq4rxVQnpQ.text: Super crowded place, you can just walk in to find seats on your own instead of waiting on a line. I shared 2 cakes with my friends, a slice of tiramisu and a passion fruit cheesecake. The tiramisu was really fluffy and full of cream, the passion fruit one was tart and maybe too sour for my friends, I enjoyed it though, just don't expect it to be like a regular cheesecake.

ew_icoCsCZiGfqx1owB-gg.text: Food was definitely delicious! Service was great! My 2 year old enjoyed playing and laughing with the staff! I would definitely come back. I had the calzone and it was soooo good! Everything from the drinks to the main dishes to the desserts were delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Great staff

qLCNQEAQgGoZScK1s1Xwxw.text: We chose the buffet option.Paid 13 pounds for a nice size portion of food last night- the roasted pumpkin and aubergines were very, very good! Also included in that a nice slice of spinach and mozzarella pizza- I just wish it was served hot rather than lukewarm, as it was cold by the time I got to the table. Also the price included a glass of wine.The place is jam-packed, so expect a queue to pay at the buffet line. My biggest complaint and minus a star is for some reason, they pump up the music which is so stupid when it is so LOUD to begin with. I might pop by again if I'm in the area.

2wYmQFzvIz2TEttJyQESHw.text: Ok, it probably deserves 4 stars, but I'm giving it 3.This place is actually good, I won't say it's not, the only reason it's getting 3 stars is that the service was, to put it politely, terrible. Everyone else looked like their service was great, but ours was terrible, so I have to rate them down.The food was good, I had eggs and tomatoes (low carb) and it was basically perfect, the eggs and salmon and the Princi breakfast also looked really good (though they were out of sausages by lunch on a Sunday, so my friend got extra bacon, which would really annoy me...)The atmosphere was good on our side (the more casual side), very relaxed and pleasant, though on our table our "neighbors" cycled about 4 times before we left... You could definitely have a kind of "Sex and the city" or "Friends" style breakfast here.So, why was the service terrible? We turned up, asked for some orange juice whilst waiting for our friend, that took ages to come. Then she arrived and we ordered food and drinks, that didn't come for about 30-45 minutes. Then we chased it, turns out they lost our order completely, it was another 30 minutes before we got fed. They generally didn't know where we were or what we wanted or anything, we felt kind of abandoned.Genuinely, if you're in the area, I would probably recommend going here (we originally planned breakfast club but there were insane queues, and the food isn't that good). I just can't bring myself to 4 star somewhere that I didn't have a great experience.

7yT3SItVr2WwK9IghGJ0rw.text: It was very crowded around 9 p.m. I desperately looked for a dessert shop after sightseeing at night. There were not many shops during the time. I loved a piece of pastry with strawberry. Cannoli was good, too. This one is the local dessert shop you cannot miss!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. take out of strawberry pastry and cannoli

Id7hUMnbKNJerk-3SKrHxQ.text: IT'S SO GOOD. comfortable ambiance, good service, great food.. and tiramisu!!go go go!

3yuMQiidHNBbTymH1TShEA.text: I was drawn in by the sight of cakes on a night out in Soho and ended up sharing a delightful lemon meringue pie and a chocolate cake from heaven. On my second trip I gorged myself on a very cheesy courgette quiche. The only downside to the place is the competitive nature of getting a seat on a busy Saturday afternoon

UOY3ZJhi0UaiGF6cCUbIAg.text: Where I'm from we don't have a lot of places like this. Everytime we passed it, weended up stopping in for a delicious pastry, croissant or cookie. Everytime it was delicious. The interior is modern and awesome.Its kind of loud and it seemed like most of the staff is italian so it was kind of hard to order. They have pizzas and ready made pastas as well. Good shit.

QfET4jm94cvjMLkUehCisQ.text: What I liked the most about this place was that everything tasted as if it was done with care. So scrumptious. From the pastas, to the pizzas, the biscotti to the passion fruit cheesecake... All was delicious. And the prices were surprisingly low. And you can't be authentic Italian servers and staff. Loved it!!

KeilX3bNWbJC0blaoeQKQg.text: Pulls an interesting crowd. I love how they've decorated the place. Details like sinking silver metal strips into a tile to show you the way the tap in the ladies works is just pure magic. Also check out the recessed lighting at floor level on the way to the toilets. Ok, so this review is turning into architecture porn, so let me comment on the food. Portions are filling and look good. Certain options like the very meaty lasagne or cheesy macaroni cheese may not do your heart valves any good but there are also salad options. Breads are fab. Really like their little cakes. If you have the room after your mains by all means try them - otherwise take some away for when the tummy's settled. Does take-aways as well.

nEfTqEeCxrCFzUpNZPGWlQ.text: Wow, this place is for bakery enthusiasts everywhere...save your calories for a trip to Princi and have a slice of pizza followed by a gorgeous cake - then run home to burn off the calories.

OvcktaI5inFFmUCR4GfEKw.text: I've been here two or three times already, for coffee and lunch. I've tried the thin bread with olives, one salad with roasted pumpkin and another with aubergine (really good), some pizza al taglio, the espresso macchiatto (they don't charge extra for soya!)... Everything was great, but I have to give this place 3 instead of 4 stars for two reasons. First, I find really annoying the no-queue queuing system. You never know who arrived before you or when you're supposed to be served and the result is that when it's very busy, someone will be rude or angry with you with a high probability. Second, it's usually so crowded that eating here becomes a stressful and unpleasant experience. Either you wait ages until you find a table, after fighting with someone for it, or you eat standing anywhere, with your coat on and everything. I know this is not Princi's fault, but still it's something that influences my opinion of the place. Oh, and I've also tried the tiramisu and the passion fruit cheesecake. I didn't like the last one, which was very disappointing given all the rave reviews about it. Tiramisu was fine, but overall I think the desserts are a bit pricey for what they are.

FDZ6Gl-KwiEsAU9LKnxStQ.text: Great Italian food and friendly Italian staff. But hey £4 for a Sicilian cannolo? That is over the top. Anyway at least the food is excellent!

5nkg4pAHYW-GP7yGMgugpg.text: I'm going to make a bold claim here - Princi does the best Cappuccino in London. The decor is wonderful, the pastries are divine. The queuing system..well there isn't one...but once you;ve mastered that, or have experience of cafes in Paris in which case you'll be fine, Princi delivers on every front. It might even be so good as to make me want, yes want, to visit the West End.

oDh8qp2sAjUQH2F54VkzzA.text: Wowww what a success and a tasty italian eatery you can find anything here always packed and everything tasty and all the workers very friendly and smily most are Italian background , and must place to go and eat in London Soho area ....

8BKWxdZuA1fWQ5GvTU4JHQ.text: I usually always get loast in the streets of Soho looking for a bar i have been t the previous week after a few jars and come across little gems like this. The seasoned Sohonian i was with insisted we go to this bakery, and im glad she did. The bakery had food along one whole side of the cafe, a bar at the end and a water feature along the other side. It was early Thursday evening and the place was busy but we got served straight away and seats were avialble - the food was stunning and with alchol being served as well it is a great combination - def recommended and i am looking forward to my next visit some time soon.

vFwqJrPoDCOg_w15ruLcew.text: the ordering process here is quite confusing, but once you get a server's attention, then you can get some nice baked goods and salads.  i got a slice of pizza which was tasty but quite small for the price.  you get your drinks after you pay, so you are basically carrying your tray all around.  it gets quite crowded and stressful, and if you're holding a ton of crap after xmas shopping like i was, it could be overwhelming!

BQBBm_3TvmvgaS4C1FIpoA.text: This Milanese bakery/cafe is very swish. There long display counter gleams with delectable cakes, tortes and pastries whilst further down is the savory selection, mostly bread based, such as stone baked mini pizzas, bread twists, pretzels and tarts. Everything is golden brown and oh-so-delicious looking. If you manage to walk past the window here without going in then you must be a saint!The eating area consists of high polished limestone tables and seating blocks, the lighting is a soft yellowy glow and uplit water features line the back walls giving a tranquil, shimmering hue to everything. It's very New York and the food is more Italian-American being slightly heavier than traditional Italian baked offerings, add that to the Asian inspired decor and you have a three way that works pretty well together.There are always big chunks of cake to taste on the counter at lunchtime so you can nibble away whilst you wait in the mildly hectic serving system (there's no queuing, just grab someones attention), but when you do manage to, the staff are all friendly and comply with all my irritating questions such as, "Which is the nicest cake? Should I go for the chocolate brownie or the chocolate and walnut square? Or would you recommend the pear tart?" even though I've just had ten minutes to decide. The problem here is that there's just too much choice and it all looks amazing!

JJ9e9ZaAXyyv4yBRsZFSZw.text: I walked by this new cafe when I saw through the window some guy baking bread. What?? That is how you draw attention now a days and build an transparent bakery. Poor guy, I had to stop and take a picture of him (please see above). I think when it comes to a cafe, Princi is not leaning on any heritage. The place is for fast phased city people with a very modern and cool decoration. I found the hall like cafeteria space a bit too polished for my taste, but the food selection in the glass cabinets really got my head spinning. They really dress to impress, and I felt for the tiramisu.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

4mokeHByIA26UuxouEEyBQ.text: They call Princi the Armani of bread in Italy and I think this moniker fits the Lodnon branch as well. It is all as swish, sexy and stylish as pizza can ever hope to be. The main dishes are pizza and pastries although there are a small selection of hot pasta dishes as well. It's a great lunch time pit stop and they are also licensed so I can imagine popping in here for a quick bite and glass of wine before a night out in Soho. Sorry Totuck but I loved the fact that some of the staff couldn't speak English. It helped me pretend I was in Italy. Also, I think it increased the probability of a decent coffee.

awUYHRwO7fBmKDu6TsbtRg.text: Okay, so the desserts here aren't incredible for what they cost, but the service is amazing enough to make up for it.My friend and I came to Princi after failing to find the Patisserie Valerie in SoHo. We'd seen it buzzing with customers when we went to Eathai a few weeks ago, so we figured it must be good. The place was once again packed, but we managed to squeeze our way in. The first time we entered we surveyed the options (all of which looked amazing, but a tad bit on the expensive side), surreptitiously grabbed a few pieces of bread, and left quickly so we could find dinner first. When we returned, the people at the door (bouncers? security guards? hosts?) recognised us and waved us inside with a good-natured, "Back again?"While we painfully tried to decide what to get, one of the guys behind the counter came up to us and started speaking Italian to me. I was caught off guard, After attempting to respond using my limited Italian (ciao, grazie, and scusi), he switched to English and asked me what I felt like eating, if I needed any help, where I was from, whether I'd been to Italy, etc. He recommended the cake with the peaches and the chunks of cake on top (I don't remember what it was called), which my friend ended up getting. I spent a long time deliberating over my choice, finally choosing the pear chocolate cake. After paying, I wandered back over to my friend, who was chatting with another one of the servers behind the counter. He kept trying to tell her she should have gotten the brownie, but she wouldn't have it and insisted that the pistachio/fruit mousse thing looked way better. He flatly told her he was wrong, and then told us he would prove his point by letting us try the brownie. We figured he would cut out two small sample pieces, but no -- he gave us an entire brownie AND a cannoli (which I'd been eying) that he reluctantly switched for one of the mousse things after my friend said she wanted to try it. As he handed our free baked goods over the counter, he jokingly warned us eating them would make us fat. At this point, we were so thrilled by the fact that we'd received £8 of free food that we giddily thanked him, told him he was amazing and that we'd visit the south of Italy sometime (he scoffed when I told him I'd visited the north), and promised we'd return. On our way out, the bouncers/security guards/hosts/whatever laughed at our flailing and bid us a cheerful goodbye. Needless to say, we'll definitely be back.(Oh, and the food was great. The baked goods were all light, moist, and delicious. Probably not worth £4, but oh well. Also, if they have bread in a basket out on the counter, try some. It's amazing.)

PCWwhHHy-xzHoe63M0pK-w.text: I'd give this place a higher rating but I'm just plain tired of Yau, cram-them-in-turn-them-out style eateries around London, even if it's Italian this time instead of Japanese. Rumour from Italian friends abroad, this Princi is unlike the several dotted across Milan. Food wise, there's plenty of selection and with good quality baked goods and a small number of hot means, is a nice choice yet it's priced somewhere beyond a cafe, but is too frenzied to make it an enjoyable place. I'd rather just take the food to go and sit in a park rather than fight for the tablespace that everyone else seems to want to endure just to eat there.

vwZ3q8ilZaaD0qUkhYFiEg.text: I'm a big fan of Princi, though as much for the aesthetics as for the food and drink. It's definitely one of my favorite places to grab a light lunch or a coffee in the West End. I love Princi's concept of a trendy Italian bakery, serving freshly made pastries, antipasti buffet, pizza, coffee and drinks. It's essentially a cafe. You order what you want at the counter, pay and go sit down, no waiter service. As far as I know, the whole concept is a first in London, but I expect it to be mimicked extensively going forward.  Everything is beautifully presented, as is the whole restaurant itself, with great use of lighting, glass cases and even a water feature (though I think they've taken this out now). The food itself is great though I've tended to stick to the pastries and pizza and can't comment too much on the salads. Other Yelpers have commented on the price, but I was pleasantly surprised. For central London and for such a popular place, I would have expected Princi to charge more. You can get out of here with a coffee and pastry for under 7 pounds, which I think is reasonable.My only complaint are the crowds. Princi seems to be almost permanently packed, making it difficult to just stop by and find a seat. I would go here much more if I could only get a table!

JEd7kqjotVPpkDReM3QjdQ.text: I LOVE this place. From pastries to pizza to more substantial Italian food, everything looks amazing and it's a real challenge trying to select what to eat. I've had a spectacular piece of chocolate torte, good millefoglie, really good asparagus pizza, and consistently great cappuccinos. The decor is sleek and fashionable (although a little sparse on seating when it gets busy).

EjNpM6oaok2tTjLI4j-KCA.text: great freshly baked snacks and sandwiches. olive bread sticks are outstanding!

qfW15alohzuXAhcIERfZTQ.text: Get ready, get set, lunch!Ok.. So you kind of have to been in the mood to come here. It's definately worth a visit, but do know in advance; it's a loud, bustling, fast paced quick serve restaurant. You place your order at the counters and then go find a seat. At 3:40 in the afternoon, it was BUSY. I almost forgot I was in London for a moment too - the employees had thick Italian accents (which I suppose is a good sign for an Italian place).There is SO much to choose from on the menu, make sure you come hungry or with friends so you can try a few different things. If you get caught with your mouth open, salivating over all the tasting pastries cakes and sweets, you better be ready when they ask what you want to order.I tried two side salads - the Chicken Garbanzo and Pumpkin Ricotta for just 6 pounds.They were delicious. This is the kind of place you'll have to come visit more than just once so you can try a few different things. I know I'll be back.Tip: They are open late and serve great, coffees and teas!

mmuI3kPh6gKml89WQCD-Ow.text: When I was a little boy I hated chicken, mainly because of the squidgy fatty bits. My mum found a way to make me eat it by mixing it with mayo, and sliced green apples in a sandwich. She called it the ghostbuster sandwich. I loved it. Princi now make a ghostbuster sandwich filling just like my mum's. They add avocados to the mix too. Tastes great. Go get some with some slices of in house freshly baked bread. Goddamn it's good. The pizza's are also amazing but be careful when choosing your slice as some have no tomato sauce and can be a bit dry. If you really must  have a sauceless pizza then get some tomato and mozzarella salad as an extra.The portions are ridiculously humungous. The decor is fantastic, exactly the same as the Princi's in Milan darling. Love everything about this place. Go there now! Oh yeah and get the fresh oj mmmm

TOZs6YpEv72pDcfYGD3jTQ.text: As this seems to be the place where a lot of people meet over coffee for a catch up or the spend the rest of the afternoon nattering away to their friends, diners like us have no choice but to stand & eat or to wait until the food has gone cold before they could find a seat! This is the major problem with Princi. Lovely restaurant, good food but lack of space. This is why I'm only giving it 4 stars rather than 5 stars.I have been there a few times and I have to say their food is very delicious, unlike many other Italians I've been to. I still have to try their dessert/cakes. I've been told on a numerous occasions how delicious they are but by the time I finished my main dish, I was too full to order any cakes/desserts. Their gnocchi and pizza are my favourites! It is not like any other pizza you get. I've never been a fan of pizza since the day I was born (yes I am odd) but I do admit I love their pizza at Princi. This must being saying something!I think the price is definitely value for money especially witht he size of the portion...! A definitely must try but avoid Saturdays as it gets very busy!

-0vR2v0lOnZVLjzGSD515w.text: This Milanese chain is taking Soho by storm, but Princi is reportedly more popular here than it is in Milan - so, for what that's worth...People talk ad naseum about the alluring sweets seen from the glass storefront windows, but I was drawn in by the abundance of breads studded with things like tomatoes, cheese and olives.  I practically developed an addiction for their green olive breadsticks (SO good), before i FINALLY ate here properly yesterday...I had bites of: A radicchio salad with cauliflower and broccoli - it was ok, but its freshness was undeniably appealing.A caprese salad with buffalo mozzarella the size of ice cream scoops - lovely.Asparagus in a cream sauce - divine.and for dessert - since this seems to be the what everyone goes here for anyway....Passionfruit cheescake - creamy and tart, very refreshing, better than regular cheesecake.Tiramisu - not the best, i didn't even finish my small slice.Chocolate amaretto multi-layered cake with chocolate ganache and amaretti crumbles - divine. High noise levels and difficult seating normally cost a place significant stars in my book, but the fact that you know what you're getting into when you walk in the doors means I can't fault Princi for being what it so obviously is - a loud, cafeteria-like restaurant, serving relatively inexpensive Italian fare with a swish streak.Not to mention, I'm still addicted to those green olive breadsticks.

IuM3T7TKmA7Z7tEJAw5GXw.text: Make that a 4.5. Oh my God. I've walked by this place multiple times, did a double-take every time (like Yee Gan's hot girl analogy), and FINALLY went there yesterday. And I am going to go back again this week.I think it took me about 10 min to settle on which type of chocolate dessert I wanted, considering there were 5 different trays of them. That was after I perused the salads, pizzas, pastas, sandwiches, etc. The whole stretch of the counter is filled with baked goods. The atmosphere is really cool too -- clean, angular layout with wide open spaces, a lot of marble/stone surfaces, and easy lighting. The bathrooms have incense lit around them. Oh, there's also a bar for the more adventurous. Princi, oh Princi. You and I are going to be good friends.

27WruwtAu89yp20KFdA97Q.text: I liked Princi when it first opened, but, after the bank holiday weekend, I have now decided it's not a place I'd really recommend, seeing as this place annoys me more than it delights these days. First, there's the whole seating issue. It's hard to get a seat if you're in a group larger than two people. Second, there's the whole lack-of-queueing system, which makes it hard to figure out whether you're being rude when trying to get served, not to mention the propensity of staff to serve anyone speaking Italian first, regardless of where they are in the non-queue. Third, most of the food isn't kept warm. There is the warm counter (so to speak) where the lasagne and pasta is served, but the rest of the food isn't kept warm. It's not a big problem for most of the food, but the pizza was decidedly difficult to eat lukewarm. I'm not sure why it was even shortlisted by Time Out as being one of Central London's best pizzas. Fourth, for an Italian place, the coffee really isn't that good. Maybe I'm more used to Australian Flat Whites and the like, but the coffee here was rather on the milky side. I've had much better coffee in Rome. Yes, the restaurant/cafe's kind of posh - like an upmarket Brek - and the food's affordable, and it's a quick option if you just want a snack or three to grab, but, all in all, the not-great service and the lack of seating means this place just gets three stars from me.

8EsK9a7WTt0UNnR1wrXRkQ.text: An authentic taste to everyday Italy, Princi is very succesful in Milan where it has many branches. The Soho version is just as good as the ones in Milan with the added benefit of the desserts and cocktail bar. Just splendid! Try the tasty pizzas, grab some really good bread and grissini to take home.

kt2wIHW-APUT83vxo0lEhA.text: Love the place. One of my favourite place in London. Have brought different friends to this place, they all love it.It's a good looking, delicious, quick and no fuss eating place.

viuFrIl7c9F9AXoj39AzaA.text: I'm torn.  I was immediately struck by the long glass cases of exquisite treats, contrasted by rough unpolished granite that lines the walls.  Everything is linnear and balanced - long counters, long rows of seating, long lines along the floors and walls. I appreciate the careful thought that must have gone into Princi's design, but...I left feeling like I had eaten at a high end cafeteria. Stand in one line to point out the pastry you want, then pay, then take your tray to the next counter to get your coffee (which incidentally took a curiously long time), then find a spot among the bank of seating with high stools next to strangers also eating off of trays...While the croissants were some of the best I've had in London, it was challenging to get comfortable here.  And if I want to eat food served on a tray, I'll go to McDonalds.

CV-gLWHc8BWH1qL0n2jhJg.text: This is another one for the "should be 4.5 stars" list.  Princi has just about every yummy, Italian, bakery food item that you could imagine.  From Pizza slices to Tiramisu.  You won't be sitting down for a long meal, but you can still completely gorge yourself.  Obviously a bad choice if you are on the no-carb diet.Seating can be tricky, as it is often very busy.  Tables are first come, first serve community seating.  There are some plinths available for use as standing counter space.  Better yet, get a massive selection of savory and sweet and go home so no one can see what a little piggy you are!

yC7RDB09Ngk22ENsqo9ePg.text: Wow, everything I ever tried here was delicious. Don't miss the pizzas and cannoli. Great espresso too. A bit overpriced, but well worth it

u2I5QftV8U3srmaMYc1EJQ.text: One of the reviewers said it best - "i want one of everything."And you will want one of everything. As soon as you get in you are greeted with plates of dessert and as you move along the line you see quiches, salads, and pastas and meat dishes and on and on. Everything looks soooo good. I DID try to order quite a few things and of course my eyes were bigger than my stomach.This was probably one of the best italian places I've eaten at...ever! This place was recommended by a friend whose husband is italian and if he recommended this place then darn right it's gotta be good!The place gets pretty crowded but you'll usually find an open table after you get your food. Bumping elbows with the crowd is well worth it. the ambiance is very modern - very balanced and supposedly they had it feng-shui approved. No wonder its doing so well.

ugJbduntKaZR8mSWqeZghA.text: "I want one of everything." - My initial thoughts when entering Princi.Princi is a fantastic espresso bar and bake shop; quite possibly a sweet fanatic's best friend and a dieter's foe. All of the baked goods are neatly arranged and look amazingly appetizing. But unlike cute desserts that don't taste like anything, the pastries at Princi are incredible. There are also pizzas and breads for those not looking for a sweet fix. I'd have to categorize making a final decision on which dessert to order as one of my biggest life decisions to date. I had a ricotta cheese tartlet and it was just so smooth, creamy, and not overbearingly sweet. Paired with an espresso, I was in heaven. The interior is very modern, with stone tabletops and little fountains. It was so nice to sit down at the bar area to relax and enjoy everything. It's definitely the place to go with a friend or two and meet up for dessert and coffee.

-G0enTQ7zsPW6r6oNB4XFg.text: If you are desperate to try this place, try to avoid peak eating times. You will enjoy the food immensely if you can eat it at your leisure. The madeleines with lavender, amazing. Everything is a feast for the eyes. The set up is long tables with stools and can be a bit of a wait to get seats together.

3Oanh8tV8jHWt26JNMxGzg.text: Extremely busy place so I opted for a takeout of Parma ham pizza and linzer chocolate cake. The staff is eager to take orders but I feel slightly pressurized to choose quickly which is extremely hard as the food scream "eat me!" I don't understand the point of the water feature but I left quickly so I would not be tempted to use the toilet! The overall design is modern. The bakery itself can be seen from the outside which does add to the charm... The pizza was tasty but I've eaten better from Franca manca in brixton. But the linzer cake was delicious in a slightly bitter chocolate way...

2fsRa24dgpk3zrWz_rmAjQ.text: The food here is great. The ambience is buzzy and fun. Were it not for the grumpy staff, particularly at the bar, this place would deserve 4 stars. Minuses: staff attitude, which is consistently less-than-happy-or-happiness-inducing, crowds, slightly high prices for portion sizes and desserts. Pluses: Great-tasting food, which you know is fresh given the turn-over, cocktails, open feel of the space.

2D16vviWnzvcOUnzurjunA.text: Good atmosphere, but somewhat hit or miss on the food... still the only place we went twice while in London.While walking through SoHo on our way back from dinner, Diner in Crime (DINC) spotted this little bakery stuffed full of people, even though it was well past 10pm. Intrigued, we stopped in to see what all the excitement was about. Imagine our surprise to discover a full Italian bakery with every sort of delicious eats you could want.On our first time through we went straight for desserts, which sadly turned out not to be the best choice for me. While DINC was very happy with her chocolate mouse thing, my experimental zabaglione based dessert turned out to be a bit of a bust. But we still loved the experience and the ambiance so much that when presented with an opportunity to return two days later, we jumped at the chance.This time we were there for lunch, and picked up some pizza on focaccia bread. While the toppings were of high quality and quite tasty, my particular piece had low topping "coverage" and so turned out to be mostly bread. The bread was good, don't get me wrong, it just wasn't pizza.So, why -- you may be asking -- am I giving four stars to a place that had two disappointing items? Because we finished our second outing with a cherry and ricotta cheese dessert that was simply out of this world. Had it been the only thing I ate there, this would be a solid five star review.Which is all to say, go there, get the cherry and ricotta thingy, and if you are tempted to get the pizza, be sure to ask for the piece with high topping density.

rSYkLoNxC9A_djeuBjpSPQ.text: Amazing breakfast of perfect scrambled eggs on sour dough bread and watercress. The jam filled croissants are delicious too.

jQQK8QbKhKHGO1U9w2CelQ.text: enjoyed margherita pizza! taste like the ones in italy. also had a napolitano pizza.  was worth the wait. desert was also yummy

hf6OqpSoljpVTubqyjmbyA.text: Popped in for a late night pick-me-up with two Italian ladies, so I am pretty assured this place is 'authentic'. Although I was too full to eat anything, I had a pot of mint tea, which was lovely. The food looked amazing and I will definitely return to try their passionfruit cheesecake. The ambience is good  very bright, clean, and modern, although I'm not a big fan of communal tables, being a very private person. The doorman/bouncer was also very good at his job, keeping two drunk troublemakers from our table.I'll give Princi a proper review once I've tried their food.

Bn2Pz5rR_l4Twv3v7g6K9A.text: Recommended to me by an Italian. So I thought I would give it a go. Turned out to be one of the better and most authentic pie I have had in London. Crust is thin, toppings were just enough for flavour without overwhelming the slice. The pasta was cooked properly. Coffee and robust and the pastries were top notch. What more could I ask for any time of the day.

t7MlgHsZuCb19V6PEGyD0Q.text: Food was fresh and delicious.  The sit down service was good.  They allowed my wife to order from the other area since she wanted a salad and I wanted the linguini.Set up is unique in that there are different food options for their two different areas.Would definitely come back here for Italian next time I am in London area.

4amcssyamn7_S8eY4TT42w.text: This was the first stop for dinner on my trip to London. Great location right in the Soho/ Piccadilly Circus area. Great variety of Italian bites including pizza, pasta, salads and desserts. The wait for the restaurant seating was too long so we opted for the counter service with self seating. Staff was patient and heated up our pizza slices. Overall, it was a good time with a chill vibe and popular Italian drinks/beer. The reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because they could improve on being more organized with the counter service at checkout time. Also, you can only order pasta if you sit at the restaurant table not if you opt for counter service.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

QW-6olSiwTzRGHz2iGiubw.text: Was so delighted that we found this cafe/bakery and so much more.  On one side of the building there are many, many hot dishes for take out or eat in...a big variety of fabulous desserts, rolls, pastries, breads...Doesn't get any better than this.  Other side of the building is a sit-down restaurant.  Appetizers, salads, pizza, calzone, rice, chicken and meat dishes, pastas galore...can't go wrong with whatever you order.  Best Northern Italian food outside of Italy.  Reasonable prices, quick bites to full entrees.

RMZ4d8EXM_-W3b_qw2-PrQ.text: Visited here Saturday night and it was packed , we had trouble finding a seat , it's set out with long canteen style tables and is very lively.We settled for coffee , pear & chocolate slice and Pasterina (ricotta & candied fruit tart) and it did not disappoint it was very tasty .There is a wide choice of Milano style cuisine from bread,cake,pizza to salads and a selection of hot food. I would recommend giving it a try!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Pasterina
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Yum!

BO4itb5nhuH2Ejt5uz-V4Q.text: Food is amazing especially the Vongole pasta, pizza is super good too. Service on the other hand is terrible, the staff is young and knows nothing about customer management.

IkDci5U7uj6NFDttKb_ySA.text: We picked up dessert from here on a Friday night. They were PACKED! They have these guys in suits standing outside to greet you but they give me the feeling of Mafioso bouncers or something. Anyhoooo, we came to buy some dessert but honestly the place must be known for their main dishes and not dessert because the dessert was at most 2 to 2.5 stars. The ambiance, decor, and scene was really key and we did not even sit in. I think it is worth at least a visit or two to try the main dishes but I don't think I would give their desserts another chance. They get 3 stars total instead of two because of the decor and ambiance.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

zgRWvD9uKpjvQpTBaWv1zg.text: Great counter takeaway Italian - fast and well priced. Olive bread and veggie pizza delicious

Tn27SO74z5rXNZMpU5_STQ.text: Had higher expectations for breakfast! Server was not very helpful and the egg dishes were mediocre at best.

yqnJHJ7ZXXLQyeg6aQpm5A.text: Lovely bit of Italy in Soho. Amazing pastries and apps. It's a must every time I'm In London. It's a great place to see and be seen too!

KBvosHqAUKm3N7zYJvcP_g.text: Prince is a slice of Rome in London. Great pastries, breakfast is awesome. Coffee perfect - the best blend of Rome and Melbourne. The photos on Yelp DO NOT do Princi justice!

8eSKIMv6HkOHnA8wAm1T1Q.text: We went for a casual girls' evening dinner and wine, and a good experience overall. I had linguini vongole, and the other girls had various types of pizza. My vongole was good, though I did wish they had bigger portions. The other girls seemed to like their pizzas. They had a reasonable selection of wine as well, ranging affordable to more pricey. Service was overall good. They did get my order wrong initially, but they were nice about it and brought out my correct order in about 15mins time. Things got busy toward the end of the evening, but I felt they were relatively on top of topping up our water, taking our requests, etc. Not a bad service for the price and busy-ness. Ambience was very casual and at times, noisy. But so long as your expectations are set, not a bad place to go for casual food and drinks.

59J6O2hVEppv4cqiil_JpA.text: Great place, but HORRIBLE service.   The servers here are non-existent at best and when you do manage to see one, they all feel like they've never waited before.  Only come here if you have a lot of patience and time!

0rRbHGjEW1qp-1ooGQeH7A.text: Wardour Street is one of my favourite spots on Londons food map and following last weekend, it just got even better.Looking for a relaxed brunch spot on a rainy day I thought a bakery/pizzeria must be the answer. Upon entering the visitor is welcomed by a long display of baked produce and a smiling member of staff eager to find a seating spot for the guest. And that is not an easy task - the place is usually pretty crowded and no wonder, really, given the quality of food and central location. Wanting to sample the bakery bit first I went for the Pistachio Girella, only to find out that these were sold out and the regular girellas were the only ones left. They were not disappointing but I already had pizza on my mind so having decided on Pizza Vesuvio I took a look around. Princi is has quite a nice vibe to it - the decor is minimal with the colour and material palette resembling mediterranean aesthetic. I was seated against a wall but that was actually nice as there is a water rill running through the entire length of the wall fed by metal taps protruding from the wall. The sound of splashing water creates a nice vibe and softens the large volume of noise. Talking about aesthetics I have to mention the toilets - nice touch, Princi. Right, back to my pizza. Vesuvio arrived beautifully sprinkled with radicchio (italian chicory - looks a bit like red cabbage) giving it a pleasant, gourmet look. The toppings included pieces of beef ragu and also olive, fior di latte and black pepper. I prefer my pizzas low in fat so the choice of beef was not spot on but still not at all disappointing. The flavours played well together, softened nicely by fior di latte.A pleasant accent was provided by the lovely waitress distributing amongst the guests pieces if focaccia (drowned in olive)Princi is altogether a relaxed, contemporary Italian eatery that delivers a proper quality without too much fuss. I liked it!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Girella
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Pizza vesuvio

pL8FahH2RDYTxVCFbZJt6g.text: We originally planned to come here for a breakfast or dinner sessions but both times packed out we found time to go for lunch instead. We were only craving the pizza so we made a beeline for their selections. There's an open counter where you can order the pizza available, you go pay and choose your seats. Definitely not table service here. What service we did gte was a bit miffed.We chose the four cheese pizza and pepperoni & cheese pizza plus diet coke for beverage. Was a little pricey for such small selections but we were hungry. We found seats by their water feature dining wall area, rather than sit at the share tables with the crowds. Because it was so busy still at lunchtime on a Thursday.The pizza slices were large and yummy but not amazing. My partner loved them more than I did so he ate the rest of mine. I would still much prefer to try this place for breakfast but it'll have to be next time we're in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Pepperoni pizza
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Four cheese pizza

z-15xVNsKqTc14HdzBJz1g.text: A delightful breakfast - great food, espresso worth going out of your way for, and warm, friendly service.The team at Princi clearly care a great deal about their work, and it shows in their food.  The 'Charcoal Oven Porcini & Parmesan Tegamino Eggs' was delightful - flavourful, balanced and generous.I'll be back for sure!

aiJJciGki9AmWMX6J0aslg.text: I absolutely loved Princi and frequented it a lot during my time in Milano. When I got to London and saw that they have a location here I rushed straight over. The Princi in London is exactly like their Milan locations - the goods and the bads. You can choose between self-serve or full serve and I would recommend the latter to access their amazing menu. Just like in the Milan location you'll deal with a slightly strange staff and a weird ordering and seating system. Bare with it because their food is worth the confusion. If you want to do it right, start the meal with zucchini fries & an aperol spritz and then end it off with a tiramisu. Vegetarians - try the spaghetti with burrata - it's really damn good. Come here if you're feeling patient and ready to have some of the best quality Italian products served up in the best way. If they could up their service and organization in the restaurant I would up my review to 5 stars in a heartbeat!

56fU2uNLb-mX5TNT1hX7LA.text: The food was really good. I kept it simple with the margarita pizza. The portions are really big  for the price they're asking. If I ever get back to London I would be going back.

b5nd6TKY7J4dF4b_7l6Tqw.text: I was very lucky to find this while my short visit to London this week. I would definitely be there again any time I am in London . Too bad we don't have that in San Francisco yet.
