Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

P6_UtbZjHYgwH-NWTGpfmg.text: This place is a gem! I'm so glad my Mom and I stumbled upon this place in Soho. The food is amazing and love the wood fire oven and bakery. A casual setting for a great break from shopping. We will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Their pasta is fantastic! Love the saffron risotto!

FWeCgSjnRjA8bfWmlqcnhQ.text: Princi.....On the plus side: great location, excellent design on the interiors (mini-water features, bench seating), brilliant ambience (a low buzz and a great feeling of movement), nice food, good music choices. Fun for people watching.  On the debit side: prices can add up if you are planning to eat anything substantial (slices of pizza are around £4.50).Highly recommended if you are looking to grab a coffee and dessert after dinner, or for a pre -drink. One of my favourite places in Soho.

_XDFBBXIwn2kvtrKSYGilg.text: This is one of my favourite places in London to eat - breakfast, lunch, snack, dinner, anytime really. The food is lovely authentic Italian with several snacks and delicacies you might not expect out of the country. The only problem is that with so much on offer - hot dishes, sandwiches, pizza, salads - you might find it hard to choose! It always seems to be overwhelmingly busy but the nature of the place is quite transient so you wont have to wait too long to get a seat. (or you could always takeaway) If you are eating alone Princi is the kind of place where you can feel comfortable at the communal tables eating quietly and watch the fast paced soho world go by. It's equally good for company too, I've introduced many people to this place and they have all loved it!

8WV2YWw6aGoDU6JAszcdpQ.text: A late night godsend. If I'm even a little bit near Princi at night and someone's hungry, this is always where I bring them. The newly expanded seating area is great, as previously it would be standing room only during busier times. Ordering is simple; get someone's attention across the counter. Not cheap, of course, but it's so so so good it's almost worth it.Chocolate cakes, pastries, mille-feuilles are all fantastic, but don't underestimate the savoury side - it's equally delicious. Their hot chocolate is also just what you want when you're facing a cold walk through Soho afterwards.

Zf7MbW97ykQm3aH9JG7TZw.text: Went here after getting "kicked out" of Hix for dessert.  The chain is based out of Milan but they've opened one up in London.  Also in Soho.  Place was rammed.  Once you enter, there are trays and trays of sweets and other dishes.  It's obviously popular for a reason.  Chocolate cake square was melt in your mouth goodness.  Younger crowd that goes for cheaper full meal before / after the clubs and bars so be prepared for a bunch of amped you twentysomethings.Only downside --- espresso is watery.  The brits need to work on their coffee.

sK4IWM3SCDKAOf9qY-o4Bw.text: You, me and Princi Sometimes when hungrier than the wolf, but want to save your last few pennies of the month on another beverage rather than an expensive meal, it can be difficult to find sustenance in Soho at a late hour. Well fellow Soho-ians look no further than Princi Princi is yet another cheeky restaurant endorsed by Alan Yau, that nauuuughty chap behind Wagamama, Busaba Eathai and Hakkasan. Princi is opposite Busaba Wardour Street. According to the lady in there, Big Alan has hooked up with Rocco Princi, and is sometimes called 'the Armani of bread'. The result is this sharp Italian bakery. The decor is cool, the prices are too. With a wide variety of breads, pizza slices, pastas, cakes and pastries there is enough choice for  everyone regardless of hunger level. There's also an abundance of samples lying around, so get your fill before you buy. There's a great atmosphere in there and the staff enjoyed (I think) a good banter about what they can suggest for the late-night patron. I can recommend the ham and cheese ciabatta (£4.00) which is not only delicious but super filling too. If you come away feeling guilty, thatr's probably because you have indulged in one of the incredible looking desserts on display. Go on, why not... You're not driving.  Princi gets devastatingly busy at lunchtime and is equally busy when I wander in there after a few beverages round 9. Having said that though.... where in Soho doesn't? Why are you still reading this? Go fill up on Princi immediately. Sexy Rob - twitter.com/RobOrme

71zOV6cCYSj9H8v9DrFl1w.text: OMG! O-M-G!! This is the best Italain place in the whole world... ever! Everything is amazing, full of flavour and just plain awesome. I will definitely go back here again, many times. Unfortunately it only gets 4 stars because it's so difficult to find anywhere to sit. It's just that busy, because like me, everyone else thinks it's great too!

Fcv9MoN8kCqzSrJ1cIv31w.text: I visited Princi thinking it was going to be a cozy if not posh café where waiters served you over-priced carbohydrates and pots of English Breakfast.What we got was a posh buffet or cafeteria.HOWEVER, the food is fantastic. I bought a slice of pizza (more like melted cheesy goodness on a chunk of focaccia) and a coke, and while the system seems a bit confusing (WHERE IS THE QUEUE?!) the food and environment is quite nice.If you're looking to go somewhere where you can be waited on - do not come here.If you're hoping to go somewhere where you can sit and talk to you friend over a cocktail, glass of wine, juice, pasta, pizza, cake, biscuits or a loaf of delicious freshly baked bread - DO come here.My pizza was room temperature (so, a bit on the chilly side) but I'm assuming this is what's to be expected with this place.If you wanted piping hot food, you'd go somewhere else, eh?It's casual, the food is good, the prices are low - what's not to like?

ijSeL_5OHYnxF-aRx_MvlQ.text: Super-duper & open till midnight! Nice interior and a large choice of delicious deserts!

8j4JCm-vz5dKbCzmDFvuyg.text: Are you hungry post the Soho night out? This italian pastry shop in its simple modern design is worth visiting. 5 of us enjoyed standing by the stone-look trash bin while sharing pistachio cakes and espressos. On Sunday mornings, Princi is also a good place to hang out watching people, pastries, wood logs, when it's not that many people, you can actually hear the wall water fall. It's also a cozy place where seats are quite close with each other, good for casual 1st dates :)Most visitors eye on the glowing deserts, although the shop also has a very good selection of breads fresh out of the wood oven. Their hours are quite good, 7am-midnight, Sun is at 9am-10pm, to cater your needs. I feel so hungry now... Thanks to John B.'s initial introduction.

-PuD0BXeNFoi96QO6I4KUA.text: Fantastic place for a quick Italian/snack in Soho. Nice funky decor. Always buzzing and full of people any time of the day. Part bakery, part cake shop, part salad bar, part hot food bar and part coffee bar. Run by all Italians, recommended by Italians. Part of a chain from Milan. I've come for lunch and snacks. Good coffee - as one would expect from an Italian place. Yummy looking cakes ( a bit expensive I think so I haven't tried any, but I love the little pastry rolls filled with ricotta - kind of like canolli but made from croissant-like pastry, don't remember what it's called but its £0.80). Great salads, great pizza, great bread. Can't go wrong really.

xL9dPFzJOdrqlPR0AgUYEA.text: We ate on the canteen side after a ten minute wait to secure seats. I had a slice of margarita pizza and thought that it tasted great -- the amount of cheese was perfect and tomato sauce was very bright. The design of the restaurant is very attractive with lights submerged under running water with their beams shining up the walls. The massive display of pizza, salad, and desserts is impressive and makes selecting just one thing nearly impossible. I doubt I will be back due to the effort of jostling for seats and the steep prices.

M0_hVBFzvfCzQiWzA5Anqw.text: This is one tasty italian deli.  A whole entire wall of glass topped counter moving from sweets to salty pastries to salads and antipasti and a smaller hot counter offering succulent sausage stew and delicious lasagna and spinach.It was crazy busy on the tuesday evening we were there and had to stand for our meal... but the heavenly and cloud- like passionfruit cheese cake made it all worth it.  And the sweet fried cracker things.Overall Princi is a great deli concept; shame it is so popular!

IsAfE4iXAbNWrlSOu3IaJw.text: This place is a gem. The great smells from outside pulled me in as I walked by. It's a little pricey...but worth it.

1i9JcXLP82w3Whh9aRNxEQ.text: I hadn't been to Soho in a while. I used to work in Soho a few years back and was always seeing new food places open up and close again, for some units, the turn over seemed to be pretty high. However, yesterday on my travels, I found Princi and for some reason I feel that this place isn't going anywhere for a while!I was immediately intrigued by how busy and bustling the place was. People were lured in by the cakes, pastries and biscuits on sale, displayed beautifully may I had.The choice is tremendous but in the end I went for the walnut brownie and took home some tiramisu, both tasty, the tiramisu was gorgeously light and fluffy.This seems like a great place to hang out for a quick shopping break or two convene with friend, it's got a really friendly atmosphere and a brilliant vibrancy to the place.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

wDLUGZ1EAlrA1_WkW4yj1A.text: This is a classy place - a very modern take on the deli concept. In the long glass cases that follow the entrance it's all about showing off how damn amazing all the food looks. Princi serves a range of different Italian goodness, from simple bakery fare including cakes and all the sweet stuff to salads and lasagne and really good coffee. Everything I've had has tasted fantastic and everything I haven't had is on the list - there really isn't much in there that I don't like the look of. The tables are set respectfully back from the busyness around the counters and up against the wall on the far side there are little fountains and a bit of a marble look going on. For a total show off it's got a really good vibe and is definitely worth a trip as it brings something new to Soho and bored taste buds alike.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

lpFid1h_2GQE3fIp80EacA.text: Walking past, I was immediately lured inside by the wood fire oven visible from the front window of Princi and the smell of fresh baked goods lingering through the doorway. The two words that immediately come to mind when I think of Princi are cafeteria and chic. Although the two words are considered antonyms, they perfectly describe this laid back and visually tantalizing Italian bakery, pasta and salad bar... where you can mix and match any combination to your liking. Aside from the sleek design of Princi, which features marble and a melodious fountain trickling alongside the bar stool seating area. The staff is attentive and courteous, often presenting patrons with free offerings of focaccia bread and pizza slices. I recommend trying the white chocolate pistachio mousse, the prices are reasonable at around £2.80 per dessert and the taste is extraordinary! You don't have to travel to Milan to satisfy a craving for the exquisite tastes of Italian cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Princi

TsKcxG0vVcP0SrI5TSzzTw.text: I don't get who wouldn't like this place? i want to eat there all the time. The first day I went to Princi, I went back again the same day for a second meal. I haven't been there again since, but not by choice. I want to go there now. They have amazing salads, and they have what looked like amazing meals, and the green olive bread sticks were AMAZING. I wish I was eating it now.I didn't get to have one of the desserts b/c I am trying to behave and diet, but they looked amazing with a plethora of options. yes so many choices I had to say plethora.

ES998ZFKY7EPpexyczmooA.text: The most impressive thing about this place is the shop window. Watching the staff bake the bread in the fire oven is amazing.   If you at all love baked goods you are eventually going to have to venture inside.When we went all we had were the desserts and some coffee but they were pretty special desserts, it has to be said. Since there were a few of us on this culinary adventure, we decided to each get a cake and share them. It is safe to say that we were on a sugar high when we left.  The prices weren't too bad for London and once you figured out the ordering process it was fairly straight forward too. The only real downside I would say is that it was amazingly busy and I have to say that I have never walked by the place when it wasn't heaving. Which meant, that we were never actually able to sit down. We had to stand at a standing table the whole time and frankly were lucky to get that.I would go again but would hope for a time when it was a little less busy.

_1muEvAdTOnnfZYw1GOW8Q.text: Yikes !!!!! I agree with Thomas W. comment " If McDonald's was Italian and acceptable. ".I give it 2 stars as the staff at this place, were really cool, very friendly with fantastic customer service. Can you belive it !!!! customer service in UK !!! wow !!!

4_3hYtOdwSGQ4bF63aoWAw.text: To use a female analogy, Princi is a head turner. When I first walked past this shop, I actually stopped and backtracked to look through the shop window.Look closely though for it is a shop of many layers. What caught my eye initially were the luscious looking desserts and cakes. Then I wandered in to continue my perusal to find that there were also salads and hot items like pizza from a wood fired oven. Finally there's a  bar area and for me, the wonderful news that they serves watermelon juice, a personal favourite.The food is Italian in origin and style and beautifully presented on the trays behind the glass counters. Everything looks very appetising but so far, I've only eaten their desserts, which have gone down well.The popularity of the place is reflected in lack of seating everytime I've been there but the sweet creations taste just as good eaten while wandering down Wardour Street.If Princi was a woman, she'd be Megan Fox!

5sveeaIBJ1ep1_CI1uIqUw.text: Food looks amazing.  One thing looks better than the next.It is a little hectic when you come in and the employees are busy and maybe not particularly helpful.  It's ok.Food is worth it, People watching is worth it.  Come in and get transported to italy.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Everything looks good
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. 4 cheese pizza. Yum!

lwwF4KmXcpn8RBwrxahviA.text: Lovely food, lovely vibes, lovely service! I came here with my husband for a lovely dinner to celebrate my bday, was disappointed as I wanted to eat fondue but it was fully booked, therefore we ended up at Princi, and let me say, this place did everything the right way! We were greeted nicely and we were directed to a waiting area while waiting for our table and was given the wait time will be 10 mins and it took less than that! Which is a +!. So we order our drinks which are one Americano and one Bellini, both got a strong kick but good! So I do recommend it. For food, my husband ordered the calzone and I ordered linguine vongole, everything were fresh and delicious, and oh boyyy they don't lay low on the cheese for the calzone! It was so deliciousssss and cheeses! The pasta? Very garlicky! Lovely! Oh oh oh, and for started we pick the classic bruschetta, yum! We ended the night with a small piece of cake, peach tart! I would definitely recommend this place, not too expensive and very down to earth! Try it!

Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Peach tart
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Calzone

xrDHJyaiyZh2B3YgUK1Kcg.text: Location 9/ 10Ambiance 9/ 10Decor 9/ 10Food 7.5/ 10Service 8/ 10Generally a cool and busy place. My low score is because the pizza was cold. Maybe I should've requested for it to be warmed up? Maybe they should've asked if I'd like it warmed up? Either way, it is what it is.... I'd have preferred a visit to good old Vapianos. But that's me... I'll give this place another try sometime soon - maybe.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. A very limited selection of foods available,  Nice but cold pizza - unless I missed something.  Generally a cool hang out, that's all!

x937MGklxCJOsCZjOZPhlQ.text: Wow, I'm so upset that we didn't find this place until the last day we were here... we stopped in because I'd been looking for a crossaint and wow, it was one of the most amazing.. buttery pastries I've ever had in my life. Having made crossaints from scratch before, I have a true appreciation for how much work went into making that pastry so incredibly flaky and layered. The service is fast, there were a lot of people standing around but the attendants behind the counter were incredibly attentive and very efficient at serving everyone -- especially since there was no formal line, there were people just standing all up and down the counter. It's a beautiful little spot, tons of seating and the perfect place to start your day with a coffee and breakfast/morning pastry. I can't speak for the atmosphere/food after breakfast time but I will *absolutely* be back next time I'm in town every day for my morning coffee.

2dhND8WRJ0g1BSgQ7RmiuA.text: So, I wanted to get a ravioli and spinach from the express side but they told me that I had to wait 5 minutes like 3 times since they were still making it, but they kept on telling me that it was coming. Seriously? After 20 minutes and getting tired of waiting, I decided to just get a table first. I accidentally went to the restaurant side of Princi and so when they gave me the menu, I thought I should just order from here.I waited for the linguine vongole for a while, around 15 minutes, so I was a bit pissed. Luckily, the pasta was incredibly delicious. You can taste the perfect combination of the olive oil, garlic and white wine. It was a feast in my mouth. The clams were also really well-cooked. I loved the food and the waiter was also super friendly, so that's why this place deserves 4 stars. The place looks pretty fancy, even with the takeout express pizzas, pastas, salads and foccacias. Hope they work on their ability to manage the wait. Would definitely come back next time. Hopefully, the ravioli & spinach will be there!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Linguine vongole!

ZnNeXZu4Dkl1Pqlb7BHrJA.text: Used to be great but now queues are long, staff can be rude and get orders wrong and it just isn't as friendly as when it first opened. Most of the food still tastes great though, so still 3 stars.

OFEgD_IqFmMackoI-tb1Ag.text: BROKEN GLASS from the insufficiently cleaned floor became lodged in my sister's foot and caused BLEEDING. I rushed to explain to the person at the counter, Caroline, who happens to be the manager. Her first words were "that's impossible". She did not apologize until she saw my sister was trying to clean the blood from her foot. There were several tiny shards of glass that were stuck in her foot (see photo). My sister had to remove the glass as it kept breaking up inside the wound herself, with no concern shown from Princi's employees. When we showed the manager where it happened she and her colleague found larger pieces of glass on the floor. She said that a glass was broken on the floor the day prior, which is telling how well the floor had been cleaned, much less "impossible."I was was shocked at the attitude of the manager and also her colleagues who kept saying to wait or speak with someone else when I asked for a plaster/bandage for my sister. It's shockingly bad service that does not seem acceptable for such an establishment. No one seemed to care that my sister had a piece of glass stuck inside her foot and was bleeding, much less provide prompt help. I love the food here but I would avoid this place. I as the client had to tell Caroline that it was dangerous since it's summer and many people wear sandals which she should normally be aware of. Please improve the attitude and service of the people who work here to make sure clients feel safe and reassured when there is an issue. Caroline did state that she did what she could by providing plasters, however with an attitude, disbelief and impoliteness that does not have place in such a restaurant. Please note that she took one of the shards of glass that was inside my sister's foot and then promptly brushed it again on the floor. Not only could someone get hurt again by the glass but since it had blood on it of course it is not hygienic....

q1e19cQ5ycbypyOPVE9uDg.text: I have been drinking at the bar and was on my way to another one and suddenly I felt really hungry and this place was like this big enormous Panera bread but with really good stuff probably better I ordered a goat cheese and sausage I think pizza be heated it up for me it was nice there were people eating late at night I don't know their hours but I just grabbed a piece of pizza for 5 pounds and took offI had had a few cocktails so I wanted something in my stomach I don't want to get drunk and crazy but the pizza definitely hit the spot

uGZpl0EqVM7W-euUH74-VA.text: I came to this place to try their breakfast. I had poached eggs & Avocado served with sourdough toast "my favorite dish for a breakfast ". Also, I tried their mini croissant with apricot. The eggs were perfectly cooked, and the mini croissant were exceptional. I literally I ordered a second one. Overall, the place is very nice and the service is good. I would definitely recommend this place for a breakfast or if you're craving pastries and croissants

wXtIX5O4HiNK9wOSvqchsg.text: Needed a late night bite to eat yesterday and decided to check out this place for some pizza. Brian thought it was awesome and I thought it was pretty good but nothing spectacular. All of the pizzas are as is. Literally - what you see is what you get. The slices are not warmed up for you but it seems like the norm here in London. The dough was so fluffy and chewy. We both really enjoyed it and dipped a lot of the crust in olive oil and vinegar. Dessert - there is a good variety. I went with the tiramisu since it is one of my all time favorite desserts and I thought it was average if not below average. It's one of those places you would stop at if you were nearby and wanted a quick bite but nothing you would go out of the way to get to.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

qXHKy183FY-X-W6e995EUw.text: Had a very late lunch and needed a quick late night snack/dinner. I saw this place was open until midnight on Google so I went to check it out at around 11:10 pm. Turns out they close at 11:30 so understandably they weren't preparing any more 12" pizzas. I grabbed a couple from behind the counter along with the large box of salad option. Between the roasted pumpkin with ricotta, tomato pesto, and a prosciutto with mushroom, the roasted pumpkin with ricotta cheese was the favourite but as a cold slice, it wasn't much. As for the salads, I had four (up to four options for a Large box). Wasn't a huge fan of the pesto pasta salad, but the roasted veggies were pretty good. The caprese was okay as well but it was similar to what I could get at my local grocery store back home. I would stick with the roasted vegetables. The fennel salad was disappointing and I thought the flavour was muted down. Service was fine. Quick and relatively friendly. Only thing is that the girl helping me dropped one slice of pizza (in a bag) on the ground behind the counter and then toppled the entire bag of all my pizzas and salads over when trying to hand it to me. Felt a little clumsy and lacking of care. I suppose it was the end of the night and she must've wanted to go home.I may be inclined to come back for some of their desserts. They look divine. I think had I been more impressed with their by the slice pizza, I would've given them a full 3 stars. We have some pretty amazing places for by the slice pizzas back home though and it's much cheaper than $24.xx pounds for the equivalent to what I got. I could only give this place a solid 2-2.5 stars based on what I tried.

rmbNfXHAPPPlktHD6AXESg.text: Best place in London for Italian food, nearly as good as in Milan. 5 stars all the way. Signature chocolate cake is DIVINE.

PcA98WE2XwF1MPTnDBwRyQ.text: Great taste, decorations and atmosphere.Very high class Italian style.Food is fine and using great fresh ingredients.

wu6dfzm9M3FK1JYenaToRw.text: Excellent Italian restaurant in central Soho area. Great variety of pizzas, pastas and all the italian deli. There is space for self service - sitting and quick ordering food from the bar with great selection of pre-cooked food and cold dishes, or sit in the area for normal ordering. Reasonable prices and quick service.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

0S4U0H7wwO_PUHu_9WwngQ.text: Some of the best pizza I've ever had. If you live and or work in Soho, Princi should be on top of your list for a quick slice.There are so many delectable pies to pick from, the biggest problem you're going to experience is finding the slice that fits your needs! Their sides and salads are also perfect. :)

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. try the 4 cheese! incredible!
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. so many choices!

LNTIflSsAfYe0cAnv7_xbA.text: You walk in and suddenly it feels like you're in Milan. Great atmosphere and ambiance musicGood breakfasts

Dgk7zFyhnmF8GB7CW5d5kQ.text: If you are hungering for a crapton of vegetables and salad mixes (think the type you can get at the Whole Foods pick-your-poison food bar), Princi is definitely the place to hit up. They rotate out the salad selections often, and there is a mix of straight veg (broccoli and green beans, beets, dressed salad greens) to the heartier options like chickpeas and mozzarella cubes, tuna or chicken mixes, salmon and quinoa, etc. The price points are also fair, for a half salad running about £4.50 and the full salad about £8 depending on the lunch or dinner session.They also have a selection of hot foods as well as sandwiches, breads, and pretty pastries. You order at the counter like a true cafeteria, then pay at the end of the row, and pick your seat. There's bar seating and communal tables, making for a very open and friendly atmosphere. There's also a fresh juice bar, cocktails, and your standard espresso-based drinks. Great for a late night bite to eat since they're usually open till around 11-1130 in Soho, and the place is bustling. Just know toward the late evening, they run out of salad options, so you may be stuck with only a few choices to fill that dinner plate. An efficient business model, they keep the place clean and tidy, and feeling very upscale even though it is a cafeteria-like in and out order-eat-and-go process.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Dessert counter
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Dessert counter
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Nice counter seating

57xIA4nxLpM-6TN-RlKZ8Q.text: When you need good Italian food in a casual but classy setting - with some good people watching thrown in... this is your place!  I really enjoyed the food at Princi.  This place is hopping!!  Very busy when I stopped in... but worth the wait.  I enjoyed both a pizza and a pasta... both fresh, hot, and perfectly paired with my Rose and tomato salad.  I am not Italian, but this seemed to be as authentic as it can get in London.  Lot's of young folks here... the energy is great!  Enjoy!

Yw8Wnk8qUuHqtIWnT8Q7xQ.text: As far as we observed the hygiene standards is not very high in London restaurant business, no matter how nice & popular the place, once you see the kitchen & the toilets you regret why you ate there & people don't seem to mind either! BUT this place was so far the only really fresh, clean place we found! Everything was really carefully made & served even tea & coffee had a lid so it wouldn't get cold. They are all Italian ( it's Italian pizza place) & we tried their breakfast which was absolutely  beautiful! The price range is a bit higher but it was so worth it!Oh and don't miss to try their Italian coffee.So we went back here today for lunch to try their salad & pizza. All very good but a bit overpriced.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. 4 choice salad, 8.50 pounds
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Bill for two

jzG4jUOf-PMBuQshGDD3EA.text: Came here for desserts per the suggestion of friend, and was good as a whole but not that impressing. The restaurant has two areas, one for self-service where you order at the counter and can get your food right away, one for seat-in service but need to order specific things like alcohols. Ordered a slice of pear and chocolate cake, was a nice mixture of pear cubes and ganache. Cheese cake with berry jams tasted a little different from common cheese cakes, the cheese flavor was stronger, but quite nice. Really liked the decorations and the big space. Would visit again if pass by but won't go out of the way for it

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

z7vrmoPzuGpGgu2e1XYFUQ.text: Hmm love the concept of this, but honestly the food looks better than it tastes.I haven't gone in for coffee or cakes, but Princi has sufficed in providing me dinner when Pho Cafe up the road has an hour long wait...Every time I look at all the vegetables and antipasti laid out in glorious heaps and opt for a salad, and every time I forget that it all tastes ultimately bland under a viscous coating of olive oil and dressings- unsuccessful in disguising the flavourlessness. Baked aubergine can be one of the tastiest dishes in the world, certainly it is not here. Oh and by the way- it is all cold just so you know.The vulture culture of trying to grab a seat can also be a little perturbing, initially in securing a place for yourself and dining companions, and then in maintaining it once the crowds begin to encircle you. At peak hours don't expect to be able to sit and chat once you hav finished up unless you can successfully ignore the glare of those onlooking with food-laden trays cantilevering over your head...

whxZw7Ed3Y1V9kA2GiyNtQ.text: This place is pretty awesome because it is unique, hopping and authentic.  I had a cream-filled donut-like pastry which was to die for and if I hadn't had lunch would have indulged in pizza and salads.  Yay for the beautifully displayed food, the awesome tables and chairs, the beautiful water fixtures and cool lights, great music and good vibe.  I can see how queuing at peak times could be a disaster though.

UNrcVqVkD8cRNDpRyv4flA.text: WOW LOVE IT! I fell in love with that place, which is an Italian bakery/restaurant. Prices are reasonable and the shop already exists in Milan... I tried their bread stick with olives (£1.20). It was just DELICIOUS! The bread was tasty, warm and crispy, the green olives were big. It has nothing to see with Paul's bread -the french bakery-, very hard to chew. The pasta is nice as well (I tried Boscaiola style, with ham and peas). There are also traditional lasagnas and cannelonni - mozzarella/tomato salad, very fresh. The pastries are square-shaped and good (passion fruit, chocolate-amaretto, tiramisu, pear flan) for only £3.50. The set is quite fancy and fashionable...I just disliked the fact that is was sooo crowded at noon. You have to struggle to find a seat.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

QOLCwM7Qk8FPavx2CNYOMA.text: Bad ordering? Don't you just hate it? After walking past Princi countless times salivating at their selection of cakes and pastries, I go and choose a cake which is essentially just three inches of cream. Don't get me wrong, I like cream but this had promised to be an Eton mess assembly with tiny layers of meringue and fruit too. Although the central layer remained, the bottom and top were missing (some other lucky customers must have got a bonus sugar rush). How sad. Fortunately, my friends' cakes all fared a little better and they're far too polite to stop me diving in with my fork. I'm not sure any of them tasted quite as good as they looked though and the pretencions surroundings put me off Princi a little. Where's the need for a wall of water? It just made me need the toilet. Still, if you're a fan of freebies, Princi is the place to visit. Baskets of olive bread and foccacia sit along the glass displays welcoming you to dive in. The man in front of me saw this as quite the challenge, and packed his cheeks full like a hamster. Very attractive...

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

JupY-Ta9gYx8s3lDLm99WA.text: £4.10: what you'll pay for a dry and generally tasteless chocolate torte to take away.Um, no.

AtbIrCnIp6_mYmlyXbAeRQ.text: Came here for breakfast several days and worth a return. Everything from pastries to complete breakfasts, and it was all excellent. Loved yummy tomato & cheese focaccia.Impressed that the tea was brewed loose in pot instead of just hot water and a tea bag. Service was surprisingly pleasant for a place where you order at the counter and they bring your food. Fun ambiance a definite cut above your typical cafe. Wish there was a place like this near my house or office, I'd be there all the time.

efThQ0q8BSD4SBn0zAYAIQ.text: Waaaaooooh, the food is good in here. Damn good. So good it makes me hungry just thinking about it. Popped in here recently after gazing lustfully for weeks, nay months. Finally managed to get some time and eager buddies to come and sample the delights with me. I went for the millefeuille, which was creamy, nutty and fruity and just absolutely delicious. A friend went for the chocolate and pear tart, which was just yummy though his unfortunate luck to get a tiny bit of pear on his portion... Pizza and cheesecake were also on our menu and we were so happy with our food, we grabbed some salad for dinner. Which was just so so nice, the mozzarella had so much flavour and just melted perfectly... Trouble with Princi though is the seating, it would be fantastic if you could actually sit or not have to fight for a seat or indeed a standing pillar to rest your culinary delights on. The olive bread was amazing though and according to my friends, Princi is a chain in Milan, so perhaps more of them may pop up in the future...

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

TbfIcnmkQ6PRDxOIdeAQ7A.text: I was surprised how much I enjoyed Princi. The sit-down and take-out are both great. The English Breakfast was so flavorful and rich with taste. The Neapolitan pizza was very artisan and the desserts were exceptional. I truly loved the croissants and the pretzels. A must try in the Soho district

6b6AG0K9Uxb8qw2zogr3ww.text: Princi  a really beautiful and location in Soho. Several times I considered going there, but every time I decided then that it was too full. But a few days ago, I finally went there with an Italian friend. She made me try Arancini  basically fried rice balls with a meat and tomato filling. Delicious! I also tried a pizza slice and was a bit surprised, as it was colder than I expected. But it also tasted good, even sort of cold.I really like the interior of Princi. Some wood, some natural stone, some polished surfaces. Some small water fountains with interesting light effects. All this actually makes me like this place.We were also happy enough to get a place to sit quickly, but it seems that it's often very crowded. Anyway, the food is very tasty. I also bought a bread there. Recommended.

Zwz9zP8B3S3ckMCgQRe3Iw.text: I come to Princi twice a week because of school. The best qaulity food for its price. My fav is the pasta salad with tuna and olives with aubergines on the side. Along with my capaccino, I'm truly a happy camper. You can also get a mini bread for 60p more. so so so so good. I highly recommend this place. If your in soho, give it a go. Also, their desserts look really pretty and their looks do them justice.

N4Ja77wB3-5JYEPR_TdGPg.text: Amazing lunch selection and of course a wide selection of "cakes"! Every time I am in London it is a must visit!It can get chaotic at the busy times and some folks are downright rude while looking for a table but this makes the experience all the more fun!

b96ZyAm9qKHv8IXrBwjtXQ.text: Seating can be a problem, and the service is usually middling to terrible (there's no queuing system at the counter, and they seem to like people who speak Italian more), but the food is divine.Because it gets so full, it's not really a place for a quiet meal, and the portion sizes are a little too expensive for what you get out of it. So, not the ideal place for a cash-strapped student. If you can look past the terrible service and that practically every mouthful costs you £1, then you'll really enjoy the food. My favourite thing to take away are those almond kisses With tea in the morning and slightly warmed up, they're just perfect.

QK4YLIGEc39S17lQyoV6vQ.text: Super cool high-end deli concept in Soho. Great lunch spot. Excellent selection of Italian baked goods, pizzas, and gourmet salads. Everything seemed fresh and delicious. Definitely enjoyed my salmon orecchiette pasta salad. Interior is very trendy---the wall on the far right has a row of 20 or so open faucets, hard to explain, check out the user pics to see what I mean---it's a very neat water feature.Only real downside is that it is way too popular! It's hard to get a seat!

t5xKhcf4vVNyibourVaZ8g.text: I first went to the Princi in Milan and loved it - kind of Armani meet self-service. Then they opened one in London and I am still loving it. I love that the people behind the counter tend to be Italian. There is so much food to choose from, warm lasagnas, cold salads, cakes, breads, coffee. And really cheap! I always get too much food, which I can't eat, but try to eat... Go with friends so you can try a whole range of stuff. Seating is hard to come by if you go at busy periods but at least it means the food is really fresh!

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. The restaurant, always busy!
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Must try the one on the left, pistachio mousse with raspberry top!

H_ioiUyB3N3Xukur7OoZKw.text: Super chic and very Milanese. I had a chamomile tea, which is pretty standard, but I really liked the teapot it was served it. Sometimes it's the little things in life. Also had a sample of my dining partners cannoli, which was light, creamy and lovely. Would love to go back and try some of the pizza, because it looked delicious!

z5Wn7gfx__hbZpVobliP7w.text: Love this bakery!It's very contemporary, serene and soothing (imagine that...a bakery)Food is great and reasonably priced. The bakery is tucked in a little side street away from the craziness that is Oxford St and well worth the 'hike' there. We went around 10a on a weekday and it was relatively quiet and empty...lucky us

PMlJdESbTJ3TcA5p968efA.text: What a discovery!The breads - rustic!The desserts - I ignored my waistline!The salads - divine!The hot food - can i have seconds without paying??? You can see them bake breads in the wood oven. I could stand and watch all day long :)They have crowd control on busy nights! Need I say more???

7VQhWNZcTjcIvFni0Y5wtg.text: i really loved princi. every time i walk past here you can't help but be drawn to it - it's always so busy and buzzing inside, and everyone looks to really be enjoying themselves. i visited with my parents and boyfriend, and we wanted to sit down and enjoy a proper meal. it was quite early on a saturday evening, around 5.30pm, so we only had to wait about 10 minutes (and thankfully, inside), although on busier evenings or at a later time, you're looking at a longer queue and a wait outside in the cold, so bear that in mind. you could of course choose to pick something from the counter and eat at the more canteen style seating at the other side of the place. i really love this idea for a more casual dining experience and i'm sure i'll be back to try it out at some point.as to our food and experience - we all had pizza and it was so delicious. i had the d.o.c and i'm still thinking about it days later. i think it was £12.50, but for a massive pizza and good quality, fresh ingredients, i thought this was reasonable value for money. all the serving staff were lovely, and very efficient and like i mentioned before, there is a fun, buzzing atmosphere. loved it. it's firmly on my good places to eat in soho list!

btJ2kRTfVeVBcS1ZN5K_FQ.text: I have mixed feelings about this place, because their pastries are FANTASTIC, but the savoury foods are ok. The atmosphere is GREAT, but you can never (never ever) find a seat. Also, service is always a bit rough. Three weeks ago I went in for dinner and purchased several items. Of the five items I purchase, I really did not like the taste of one (which cost me about 3 quid). I took my bread up to the counter thinking I could just explain that I did not like it and have them exchange it for something else. WRONG!!!! I woman behind the counter gave me the third-degree (as if I had personally offended her). She questioned and argued with me for 3 minutes before another employee walked over and just exchanged the item for me. Haven't these people ever heard of the saying, "customer is always right?" In any case, this...and the other negatives listed above, have diminish my love for this place. Princi is good, but definitely NOT great.PS:  Burning incense in a restaurant???   Really?  Taste has as much to do with the nose as it does with the mouth...and smelling incense when I am trying to eat a pizza is the very last thing I want to do!  YUCK!

wJk46BNKkhjjbDbJ7V3p9g.text: Fantastic! Great ambience (a bit loud), delicious food, nice wine. Friendly staff. One of my favorite spots in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom

PLlxQvhzwoid0DC2Ex9S-A.text: Ok... so the thought of how busy this place is makes me nervous and I would prefer to take my food and go somewhere else.  Actually just standing at the window looking at the food, while eating the food would probably work.When I walked in, I was instantly greeted, but of course I was still in shock looking at all of the baked goods.  The lady simply told me to just let her know when I was ready to order and she would help me.  Some of the items I could not distinguish because the sign was gone, but I was already pretty set on what I was going to order.  I am not keen on the prices as they are expensive, but some of the items are worth it.  For example the Ricotta Cake... holy fluffy, spongy deliciousness!  Not overly sweet, but rich and satisfying with a few surprises inside in the form of cherries!  Lovely!  On the other hand... the mini Madeleines were awful!  They did not have much flavour and they were hard and stale!  I have never had a more disappointing Madeleine... and that includes ones that come in a plastic package at the supermarket.I would definitely go back for another Ricotta Cake and would not be opposed to trying some of their other baked goodies... possibly some of the other food, but based on some of the other reviews, I would rather spend my arm and leg on an indulgent cake.

Hlri8pXzGHVwRYVTNk1ANw.text: Back in London on holiday and our first stop was Princi.  We were here a couple of years ago and loved the food then, we had to come back.  So happy to report nothing has changed and the food is as delicious and fresh as I had remembered it to be.  It's a casual spot, cafeteria style, with freshly baked goods, artisan style pizza, and a variety of cold salads.  My husband and I got the Margherita pizza, ham and artichoke pizza, pesto pasta salad, spicy broccoli salad, ham and cheese rolls, and meatballs (We were hungry, please don't judge.) Everything was absolutely delicious.  The pizzas have a crispy yet soft on the inside crust, the pesto and basil pasta salad was to die for, tossed with a light but tasty pesto sauce and fresh basil leaves, which was a nice twist. Princi is almost always busy, so if dining in, be prepared to wait, as its first come first serve.  FYI, the restaurant does have a small area with waiter service, but it's cool to experience the cafeteria side.  Plus you get to sample some of their more popular items as you go through the line!  Enjoy!

LhWU39n_0ziwKodgK0YGOA.text: Love this place! Went there for a quick Thursday lunch and the place was buzzing. Most of the staff are actually Italian, so there's a real authentic feel to it and you almost feel like you're in Milan itself!Sitting at the brass-covered bar table that runs along the window, I had barely waited 3 minutes after taking my order that my Coppa, Rocket and Mozzarella pizza that it was swept down before me! Very good price (11,50£) for such good quality ingredients (beautiful olive oil). All in all a real italian eatery, that leaves you with a fresh and well-fed feeling, definitely recommend.

ykdN6uvsn7WnV3da7Dpj3g.text: PRINCI I LOVE YOU!!! Princi was the best dining and service experience I had in London.  I wholeheartedly recommend going there. I went multiple times on my visit to London. On your first step inside, you are joyously welcomed by the staff. The food is absolutely delicious, and the servers are all extremely nice. One server complimented me on my outfit -- both hilarious and endearing. My only problem is that the place is really crowded, and due to that -- the lines are long.  I didn't mind, except for the fact that you sometimes can't find a spot to sit at! I also had an issue with one of my trips there -- there was a homeless man walking around on the cafeteria side and asking for money. None of the patrons said anything when I, a young girl, was being bombarded for money for near five minutes. As a young female, this was a traumatizing experience. Eventually, I was left alone and told a waiter who immediately resolved the situation. Still weird to think that you can be in a packed room and no one will help you....

v2MrnXtww8j0z109QXuDvg.text: In the heart of Soho this popular lunch spot and bakery is a bit of real Italy in London. Eat In or Take Away Princi offers tempting forget-the-calories delights from their pieces of  chunky pizza to their old world pastries. It is easy to see why people keep coming back and its laid back and stylish atmosphere makes for approachable informal dining. Or just come and buy from the bakery to take home -Their Canoli are fantastico! Around Christmas time they have authentic real Italian Panetone bread, so if you can't fly to Italy to get one, or you don't want to buy one in a cardboard box, you can pick up the real thing here at Princi.

RtWo46X9LuF7eBM6HvUz2w.text: Great atmosphere but food is a tad mediocre. Would not recommend the quattro formagio too stodgy or tiramissu the biscuit base needed work. Good coffee

LFGQRxucK1nj6-yMi3cudg.text: Best place for breakfast, lunch or dinner! Great location! Management and Staff were beyond friendly, warm and hospitable. Stayed in the area from 9/12-19, while I was in town for 2015 Rugby World Cup. Don't forget about their pizza!

5ql8G7-G3M0SLhe2yu19zg.text: cute little store, it was late night and we couldn't find a place to eat so we came here ! loved the little water fall thing at the seat / bar. Loved the lasagna ! was so yummy !

DjcCBAuSqQFR6-Mv8alNjQ.text: The service was pretty woeful - we were made to feel like we were desperately inconsiderate in having the bloody temerity to eat there, and were served crappily by four or five disinterested staff. The pizza was really good,  authentically sloppy. A little overpriced, maybe, but at the going rate for Soho. On balance, I'd advise you to try to get a table at Pizza Pilgrim, around the corner, before trying here. Difference being that Princi seats probably three times as many, so you're far more likely to actually get in immediately here than at a hipstery shoecloset. It feels like it was a retail unit in a previous life, so it's all a bit light and big. The lack of intimacy is offputting.Four-star pizza, two-star everything else.

aud_PpKcCidN8Vki6tYJJg.text: 4 stars for ambiance, but shit, being asked THREE TIMES if we need anything else (e.g. please leave now) when we're still chatting after finishing our drinks?It's clearly a popular hangout, especially late at night, so don't expect to linger without a few "encouragements" from the wait staff to buy something else or leave.Also, both the coffee and mint tea were completely average.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Silly hats are a must
Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Ordering at the counter is a bit chaotic

Bfj1P7cklrJb4b0DmZXSpQ.text: L!O!V!E! I!T!Can't do anything wrong here besides crowd control, oh and the occasional splash from the fountain if you're seated at the counter.

photos.caption: Photo of Princi - London, United Kingdom. Mmmmmm princi desserts. Yum!

oArewzERx5BsCfKh6LIsNw.text: Lovely semi-cafeteria style Italian food, from pizza to lasagna.  They also have a massive counter of beautiful desserts.  I got the passion fruit cheesecake and a cappuccino, which were both delicious.  Although more on the expensive side, the quality was definitely worth the price, and it all felt very authentic.  Would like to come back to try their savoury food.

hqz5KRz5vUfzlLtQEdkKaQ.text: The spread is mesmerizing that's for sure. First thing you see from the door is a hypnotizing spread of moist cakes and juicy tarts and piles of cookies. All the way back to the cashier you're met by all sorts of flatbreads and pizzettes, at least 3 cases full of something bready, cheesy, tomato-y with different toppings. (They often put out samples of their pizzettes and flatbreads, the extras from the oven, so you might even get full off of a few samples if you time your arrival just right!) As a concept its very enticing... go down the line, pick up your bready goodness with a few cold sides (beet salad, broccoli rabe, these types of things) or head straight down to the back where they seemed to have hot dishes ready for plating. Cashier is there too, and then you better fight for a table because once you've plunked down there's no one pushing you out the door and you can linger in the smooth space for a good amount of time. For dinner this is a nice balance of casual and still 'swanky' enough to call it a night out.As nice of a place this is to visit, I wasn't blown away by the food itself. The samples I had were pretty good, in that it was cheese and bread, but honestly not that hard to mess that combination up. The pasta I had was way too salty, so much so that I ended up eating the mushrooms and throwing the bulk of the linguine out. And the desserts are beautiful, often interesting combinations, but the flavors don't really come together. Appearances can be deceiving. I would go back... but mostly to gawk.

PmhWI8HJT-THO7YKWiLJvw.text: Alan Yau has created some of my favorite restaurants in London so when Princi happened to be on my nostalgic walking tour of my old town it was the perfect place to stop for lunch. It's nothing like the other restaurants on Wardour street. "Sleek Milan hotel" just about describes it. It's very casual communal table seating inside but still very chic and cosmopolitan. There's a seated pizza place on the left and the buffet is on the right. You just go up to the buffet counter and let the staff know what you want. They'll put it together, reheat the food and you just pay at the cashier as you pick up your tray of food. The pizza's are okay (less than £5 a slice). The real stars are the dessert so be sure to save lots of room for them. We got the peach & pistachio cake and zuppa ingress (super rich and filing). Afterwards we were satiated until dinner. Couldn't even consider an afternoon snack even though we ended up walking over 10 miles.Next time I would skip the lunch and just come here for afternoon tea.Approx £20 for lunch included two pizza slices, two desserts and a coffee.

u4oAoT8pIQZrEodLR1W6Sg.text: This is a fantastic, authentic Italian pizzeria.  The service was excellent and the spicy sausage pizza was Devine. I highly recommend this yummy eatery for a quick and reasonably priced lunch or dinner in Soho.

nKcgUWNaBTy2nSYFP3mpjQ.text: A variety of savoury dishes as well as a vast selection of desserts and pastries. It's perfect for a quick catch up with friends and a spot of afternoon cake or even pre-theatre dinner. Don't expect to get much personal space or private area though as the seating is mainly canteen style, we had to queue for quite some time eating at the restaurant area.

iwAz9DKGMQYyILI4uExUyg.text: Princi has the quick and go side and the sit down restaurant side. If you can get a seat on the pick up side it's nice and food is great as are the cocktails. On the restaurant side I'll say that even though two of the pasta dishes arrived cold and half the table would get their food while the other half waited the food still tasted good. The problem was that it wasn't good enough to overlook the slow and poor service. The waitress was friendly but perhaps they more help or better organization.

FT0BGCseIBOCYeJHpCInbA.text: The baseline: not a good value.The deets:This place is always hopping, and that seems like a good sign, but apparently, in this case, just indicates a place that's gotten hip with a particular clientèle and is riding on the coattails of that popularity.The bouncer (yup, bouncer) at the door is a sweetheart. He shows you were to wait in line to have your name taken for a list for a table. This is a convoluted process, and causes a clump of people to essentially block off part of the restaurant, standing awkwardly against one wall in the hopes that the head waiter (presumably?) will notice them.We waited roughly 40min for a table for three, and ended up with window counter seats, which were fine, except that the counter is polished brass and the pendant lights cause a glare right into your eyes. Seriously ow.Our first round of wine came with bits of cork in it. Not ok. Appetizers were staggered: two of us got food, one of us waited. The same happened with the mains, but to an even worse degree: two of us got our pizzas and the third came out 30min later because of some temperature issue with an oven (which sounds like a convenient excuse for "we dropped/forgot your order". That meant two of us sat there letting our pizza get stone cold so the third wasn't staring at us stuffing our faces while her stomach rumbled.The highlight of the meal was the olive oil and balsamic vinegar served with the bread (which you have to order, where most places will give you a bread selection gratis), which were of exceptional quality.Service was spotty and understaffed. And the bungling of the order pacing was just unacceptable at this price point, for which the food didn't make up.Skip.

SyCvy8w2WeQvnG06as4Wyg.text: Beautiful spacious italian place. Lots of freshly baked pastries and a good options for breakfast. Prices are a bit higher then basic considering the size of the meal but it feels like everything is with more quality and less greasy. I also liked the fact that they heat up their pastries before serving them, which is not common in London.

6MZBIukUfCL-HDhqx8X8DQ.text: This faster than fast place definitely helps busy people to get delicious & nutritious lunch almost on the go! the service is so super fast and - let me say - dedicated - grabbing our napkins, empty glasses before us realising we are done with them. Today, I had a chicken and roasted parsnips and sweet potatoes and honestly cannot remember time when I got excited about eating chicken. This plate was full of flavour and juiciness! My girlfriend's plate of four different salads were so delicately different and vibrant - aubergine with tomato kind of salsa, beetroot & goat cheese and some mysterious items.. Ocean of super tasty healthiness in my mouth.Disappointment came with the favourite part of meal - the desserts.. My girlfriend said that my dessert tastes like armpits; Hers was this enormous pile of over sweeten clotted cream in three thin pastry layers. In fact, both of the desserts seemed like they are trying to beat a World record in amount of sugar in a piece of cake.Thing which must be mentioned is the restroom. Large individual room, luxuriously and really clean looking, smelling of incense helped me to get over the dessert disaster rarely fast..So would I recommend this place for a date or weekend relaxed meeting with friends? Probably not. It really doesn't give the chance to relax and slow down properly (AND enjoy the dessert), but it is amazing place to go to for a lunch break or a quick bite.

nitPu23FtHDggItbhgB-2w.text: Really good italianfood. Good Pizza, good Antipasti. They have also a lot of sweets and Free wifi ;)

NbW0cTR4ZOXyXa0FYmpmXw.text: Stopped in for a quick snack and had the sliced pizza.  It was the most delicious thing I've ever tasted. Beautiful sauce and perfect crust. I can't wait to go back.

4plRv93aRB1-j5Ozdsh3ig.text: The food is laid out in front of you as you come in from the relative bustle of Soho, and you know you've arrived. Princi is somewhere I've gone past on several occasions but only recently stopped into for a fantastic coffee and canoli.We ate in the food-displaying side (on the right as you go in), which seemed to be the drop-in area. The macchiato was fabulous, with the fruitiness of the coffee coming through (surely the sure sign of a good roaster). The canoli was fab: sweet and creamy, firm yet crumbly.One downside is that ordering is fairly convoluted, in that you have to stand near the thing you want (cake, patisserie, salad, pizza... all amazing) and get the attention of someone serving, and hope that no one butts in in front of you. You have to then go and collect your coffees from the back, which makes coordinating slightly difficult, but not overwhelmingly so. Additionally, the water feature around the edge of the room spits out drops of water over the table area, where your food, drink, book etc is likely to be...goodness knows what's been in contact with that water. This for me is almost a deal-breaker, and I'll make sure to get a seat at the tables in the middle of the room.

Mnz1g6pPWXfx8jT-V5Yhgw.text: Hmm. GREAT service from the man at the door. They were closing but let us and others stay past the door hour. However, we liked the food and options and prices. But I saw the displays - many things on trays or right up on the counter (rice balls and sausage rolls) which were not heated. I ordered veggie lasagna and asked if it could be heated. "It IS heated" they told me - so we go and sit down...ALL our food was room temperature if not cold. Not good. If they only had warm or hot food this might get a 4 star review. But after being told they would not heat when asked, we didn't bother again, Sad.

kh8XIyARdjiAAT6DnInrpg.text: I always make it to princi when I'm in london - its a quick walk from Regent Street and has a good variety of salads, desserts and pizzas!

bzHTyixA7710W9mkUNZ-Sg.text: One of my favourite places to come grab a quick bite, only downside is that it's usually very busy and hard to get a seat. Recently been discovering more of the restaurant side and it's really really good. The pizzas are very authentic, I especially love the D.O.C pizza, with beautiful Italian tomatoes and buffalo mozzarella.

yXwVCPdYB4uxPbFqLJV_vg.text: One of my favorite London/Soho joints to take a break from pounding the streets of London.  Large ish and naturally contemporary styled place with rows of communal tables serving  Italian bites, coffees, bakery items and, Dolci. Most items are prepared and staged behind glass counters so just point, pay and eat!!

0RA-XqsmDPRoRDIqI35WjA.text: Croweded, in demand, and seems to be Italian indeed, but the food was not great, just ok, service was ok and the desert was ok...so all and all it's an ok place, not great...

OYteloINDrxPlvQL1wFKCA.text: If you have a chance to eat here, you must! I went for dinner with one of my friends, and it was one of the most memorable meals I had in London. Definitely the best Italian food or pasta I've ever had. It's a fun, bustling atmosphere. You can choose to sit down and have waiter service or just get a slice of pizza and/or pastries from another section of the place. I got the pasta alla norma, expecting it to be just ok. However, it was not just ok, it was amazing! It was pasta shells with a tomato + eggplant sauce and fresh mozzarella and basil. The sauce was the best pasta sauce I've ever had! The service wasn't the best because it was so busy, but the meal was so much fun and so delicious. Definitely eat here!!

moDIZpo4XiQm_mxeHZl1Mg.text: Always very busy to find a table. Nice interior and friendly staff. Real italian fresh good. Every time we come to London we have to eat at Princi. We love it!

mRELZtLuAHQAqv8hkbTOXA.text: I come to Princi every time I'm in London for a Cannoli and a Coffee as its amazing.The food is incredibly reasonably priced, the pizzas are amazing and the staff are so blummin' lovely!

YN5f_fm_bmAPV3w_6rPSfg.text: Real taste of Milan in Soho! Italian bakery chain offering also hot dishes and drink, as well as a sit-down pizzeria in the left Very nice to come here for an Italian Aperitivo (they make a pretty good spitz at the bar) or for a quick lunch diring shopping days.Do not miss the focaccia allo stracchino (focaccia bread with cheese), I love it!

F43xenraDPnEvkTVUQZM8w.text: High quality Italian food in a convenient Soho location.  I went here in the restaurant' s first year and the unique interior design drew me in. I like being able to watch the bakers in action right near the entrance. I ordered the tiramisù for dessert and it was magnificent! Princi just needs to bring down its prices and improve the seating arrangement for it to be a five star Italian eatery.

oBKmrmbUKFJZJmaLTceruA.text: I have seen an earlier review call this a "semi-cafeteria" and I would agree with that.  I paid around £8 for a slice of nice pizza and a tuna/cherry tomato focaccia.  Fairly simple but tasty fare and not horribly expensive considering you are just off oxford st.  This place is good to drop into if you are heading somewhere else in soho or off to a show on Shaftesbury avenue.  Just be prepared for the busyness and the NOISE.  The music is played at style bar decibels which leads everybody else to almost SHOUT.  There really is no need for such VOLUME and they could do with dropping it a tad.

0f2-qBh4B0pMz5F5cPXDkQ.text: A place where u won't go wrong with whatever you choose Vast collection of deserts and one of the best pizza places in London

WTkawJZXs2CDZJ11lUpNJw.text: Just the Charcoal oven to gaming eggs for breakfast on Sunday. It was great. At that time it wasn't crowded and had a nice atmosphere, with light classical music in the background. Staff very friendly and helpful. I've passed by this place a hundred times and happy that I finally stopped to try it.

hXMyEwjTE2Rh34G4d7Vycw.text: Food is just ok. The location is good in the heart of Soho area. BUT It feels like a cafeteria (not in a good way). The staff has an attitude problem. Won't return.

dazV8gfKnSAsqEDFiNSRzQ.text: I think this place would be good for quick take away lunches, as they have a wide variety of dishes at the counter. But their table service is pretty awful. I live next door and wasn't interested in going far for dinner, so we headed to Princi. It was a Monday night of a bank holiday weekend, so they were packed and everyone looked frazzled. We waited for a few minutes in the line to get our names down and asked how long it would be. The woman said they were very busy, (I can see that, which is why we asked) and said, maybe 25-30 minutes. Well, its a busy night in Soho and half an hour isn't terrible so we bobbed and weaved around the people ordering at the counter and got a half bottle of wine and waited. As for the atmosphere, at first it seems nice and open and very modern, but all the tables are high and so close to each other that squeezing into a seat is a pain even without a tray of food. Anyway, we managed to snag some seat at the wall and waited, and waited, and waited, and waited. They send you a text when your table is ready, so it was now 50 minutes since we put our names down, so we went back up and asked to make sure we didn't miss a text or something. The same lady then told us it would be another 15 minutes! OYE! I don't mind waiting an hour for a table, if I am told it will be an hour. She just kept saying how busy they were. Yes, I see your are busy and so you should have over estimated my wait time. We now felt like we had committed to this place, so we stayed and got seated about 15 minutes later. So our 30 minute wait was now over an hour. When we finally got seated they told us that the pizzas were backed up so they would take longer than usual too, so we settled for a couple pasta dishes. Oh, and it took us forever to get a waitress, because she was so busy chatting up the customer next to us. Then as a topper on the cake, my boyfriends pasta was undercooked and mine was literally burned - like black and stuck to the bottom of the dish it was served to me on. I was so hungry at this point I just ate what wasn't stuck to the dish. When then manager came by and asked us how things were we did say something and she offered to bring me something else, but I just couldn't be bothered at this point.I think the manager (or who I assume was the manger) stepped up and took the food off our bill, and because of her good will I'll probably be back - on a quieter night. There has to be something redeeming about this place if they have 4 stars on yelp.

QH2-H3G_Lgumbv3aksSZVg.text: Really great Roman stile thin crust pizza in this spot, as well as awesome rustici - the savoury bites with cheese and ham or cheese and spinach. Watch out for rush hour - its bakery gets crowded! Don't forget to grab those cannoli.

nLS_iuSkbzWQT7UvhRqvKg.text: This might be blasphemy.  But I 'm not a fan of British desserts.   And although the desserts at Princi are supposed to be Italian, they taste British.  They look Italian, but they're as Italian as a fake Gucci bag.Overall it's a cool atmosphere, communal dining, dozens of pizza slices, desserts, bread to ogle at.  It's a great place to wind down after dinner with a glass of grappa, espresso, wonderful selection of tea.  Don't be fooled by the long line as it goes by pretty quickly.
